name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, human rights abuses must never go unnoticed by the EU, no matter if they occur within or outside of its borders. Therefore we cannot let certain worrying political developments in Malaysia pass without comment. Howard Lee, a Malaysian Assembly Member and president of the International Union of Socialist Youth, and other activists were taken into custody by the Malaysian police for participating in a rally. They were arrested because they called for clean elections, clean government, the strengthening of parliamentary democracy and the right of dissent. Although they have been released – just today – I would ask you, on behalf of the European Parliament, to address this issue in the relevant fora so that it never happens again.

text: The final draft agenda for that part-session, as agreed by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 17 November 2016 under Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed.Monday: No changes Tuesday: The ECR Group asked for the title of the statements by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the West Bank and in the settlements to be changed.The title should read: "Challenges of the Peace Process in the Middle East".

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! So we propose to actually change the title of this debate from "The situation in the West Bank, including Jewish settlements", to a more general title: Challanges in the Middle East Peace Process, because we all believe and know how we all sit in this room that in the Middle East, this region is much more complex than just the issue of Jewish settlements. If we, as Parliament, want to contribute to the peace process in the region and really consider all the reasons and aspects for this peace process to move forward, then we should have a more general discussion and not just focus on one issue. Anyway, all the reports, including what the Quartet writes in its report, indicate that the problem we are talking about cannot be reduced to just one issue. Therefore, we are asking for a change of title and a broader debate, so that we can all comment on different aspects of this tragic process, this tragic conflict, and propose our contribution to solving this problem.

text: .- Mr President!I do not think we should use headlines in our debates and in our cases that distort reality.The last time we had a vote here in the European Parliament on the situation in the West Bank, Palestine, the turnout was around 500 in favor and 150 against.I think it is absolutely clear that we should keep the headline we have, and I therefore want to oppose Zdzisław Krasnodębski's proposal.

text: I will put the motion to the vote.(Parliament rejected the request.) name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, 89 Members from five Groups have proposed a resolution calling for the opinion of the Court of Justice on the compatibility with the Treaties of the proposed agreement between the European Union and Canada (CETA). The resolution is currently scheduled for Wednesday, but is only to be put to the vote. I request that this resolution be debated on Tuesday and demand a roll-call vote on my request. There is no reason to avoid debate: many statements are coming from stakeholders, the expert Community law professors, and even the Advocate General of the EU Court of Justice. Furthermore, after the objection by the Walloon Parliament, the Council has supplemented CETA with a joint interpretative instrument. The legal validity of that instrument is unclear, and this further adds to the complexity of the agreement. So it is necessary to ensure that the suggested investment court system is compatible with EU law, and all these considerations and this House’s interests require that the Members have the possibility to express their views before this important vote.  (Applause)

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: - The GUE / NGL Group fully supports the Greens' request. The CETA treaty is a large and far-reaching treaty with very far-reaching consequences for our regulations, our decision-making, our legal system, the precautionary principle and our economy. In particular, the Investment Court System (ICS) is a highly controversial part of the treaty. During a public consultation in 2005, its predecessor, the Investor-State Dispute Settlement System (ISDS) received 150,000 responses, 97 percent of which were markedly critical. Some of those errors have been corrected in the investment court system, but essentially ICS is the same system as ISDS. This has been argued by a number of leading scientists, including Canadian professor Gus Van Harten, and has also been demonstrated in a study entitled “Investment Court System put to the test” by a number of leading NGOs. They have shown that the most controversial ISDS cases under ICS can still be conducted with the same or an even worse outcome. It is true that the Legal Service of the European Parliament has said that it does not expect any problems with ICS, but on the other hand there are letters from the European Association of Judges and the Deutsche Richterbund disputing that. We need to be able to talk about this topic.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! People are worried: what is in store for us? What is happening in globalization? How will our companies and jobs compete with countries like China, India and Brazil? With our trade agreements such as the one with Canada, we are responding to these concerns without curtailing our democratic decision-making space. We give rules to globalization without endangering communal services of general interest, art and culture. And we secure our environmental, social and consumer protection standards and also ensure a good future for our agriculture. That is the belief of the vast majority here in the House. Ladies and gentlemen, of the 89 colleagues who tabled the motion, 82 voted against the latest trade agreements here in Parliament. The colleague Jadot writes in a press release: The Greens will do everything to destroy the CETA. Our colleague puts it in a nutshell: it is not about giving answers, but destroying them - destroying trust in our European institutions, destroying trust in our legal service and also destroying confidence in us MEPs. Ladies and gentlemen, we are not participating! The opinion of the Legal Service of our Parliament clearly states: Effects on the EU legal order: none, Effects on the distribution of competences in the EU: none, Effects on constitutional and fundamental rights: none. But again: This is not about testing, but about destruction. And when you see who just applauded on the motion: the Greens and the populists - they are looking for applause from the wrong people, as they have so often in the past two years. Quit populism and get back into the ranks of the Democrats! We reject your application. We promote the CETA. We want to shape globalization and give people good answers. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Ramon Tremosa i Balcells on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015 (2016/2063 (INI)) (A8-0302 / 2016).President Draghi is still on his way here due to a delayed flight, so we will start the debate first by giving the floor to the rapporteur, Mr Tremosa i Balcells.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, we live in times of uncertainty where future stability in our economies cannot be taken for granted any more. In this context, the biggest reassurance we can have for the future is the ECB’s safe pair of hands. ECB policies have been correct in general terms, and tomorrow I hope this Chamber will clearly endorse them, as we did in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) some weeks ago. ECB policies are subject to improvement and critique, of course. In this report you will find several ideas that may be of interest to you. We believe, for instance, that the asset purchase programmes (APP) should be redirected away from buying public debt into investment assets related to the EIB. The ECB should try harder to buy assets, such as a new wave of project bonds related to EU projects with clear EU added value, for example assets related to the building of the trans-European network of energy and transport, which is fundamental for the economy of the eurozone but lacking in proper investment in some Member States. These European projects related to the Energy Union and the Transport Union were voted through by a large majority in this Parliament during the last legislature. We need investment, but smart investment: no more airports without planes; no more high speed trains without passengers; no more roads without trucks or cars. I believe that the current APP is being used by some Member States to avoid necessary reforms in the fields of late payments, energy reform and public deficits. We also ask the ECB to study how it would impact the European monetary policy if Member States issued debt directly related to public investment so that the ECB could buy it. This may give incentives to Member States to increase their level of investment in research and education. We are also worried about the effects of negative interest rates in our banks and in our economy if they are maintained in the medium term. We know that the ECB is aware of these downside risks. I hope that negative interest rates will be the first measure to be unwound. We express also our concerns in the report on the creation of housing bubbles in many big cities in Europe, such as Barcelona, where I come from. The cities are more and more expensive due to international capital inflows. Ultra-low interest rates are partly responsible for it together with, of course, local mistakes. Income inequalities are also worryingly on the rise. Finally, we call on the ECB to study in depth how small saving banks and big banks react differently during the crisis on the concession of new credit. So we ask: are healthy and well-managed, small saving banks a key part of the rapid recoveries in some countries of the eurozone? I also ask myself in this Chamber, do we need to balance concentration at the big bank level, which is happening in some Member States, with a new wave of small banks linked directly to their local territories? Dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, I really look forward to your views on all these issues.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ramon Tremosa i Balcells, and all the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs for their work on this report. Ex—post assessment of the ECB’s activities by the European Parliament is an important part of the democratic accountability of the ECB and a necessary complement to its independence. The ECB’s independence in the conduct of its monetary policy, as enshrined in the Treaties, is crucial to the objective of safeguarding price stability. The Commission shares the view that the ECB’s unconventional monetary policy actions have had a positive impact on overall financing conditions in the euro area. The implementation of the measures previously announced by the ECB is expected to lead to further gradual improvements in financial conditions and help bring inflation closer to the ECB’s objective of keeping inflation rates below, but close to, 2% in the medium term. However, we also share this Parliament’s view that a prolonged period of low, or even negative, interest rates represents a challenge for the European financial system. While low interest rates are necessary to support the recovery and have had some positive impact in the short term on financing costs and capital gains for banks, a protracted environment of very low or negative interest rates would be a symptom of persistently weak aggregate demand and overall macroeconomic conditions. As emphasised by Mario Draghi a number of times, we cannot ensure a sustainable recovery with monetary tools only. EU Member States must make wise use of the time provided by an accommodating monetary policy and advance necessary structural reforms, while continuing with responsible fiscal policy. Moreover, within the European Systemic Risk Board we have worked hard to assess the financial stability risks that may arise from a prolonged period of low interest rates. We are aware of the risk that this poses both to banks’ business models through depressed net interest income and for insurers and pension funds with fixed liabilities. We have policy measures in place to address the most severe risks and are continuing to monitor developments in this issue. I look forward to a fruitful debate.

name: Thomas MANN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen! The economic and financial problems in the EU cannot be solved by the monetary policy measures of the ECB alone. Their aim is to stimulate overall demand. Mario Draghi is right: we need balanced structural reforms and sound budget management in all euro area Member States. Cyprus, Ireland and Slovenia are good examples. They were able to reduce their deficits below the reference value of 3% of GDP. This is exactly how positive, sustainable economic and financial development emerges. In 2015 the ECB expanded its asset purchase program. 1.7 trillion euros are earmarked for this by March 2017. This now also includes bonds from non-financial companies, as well as from local and regional authorities. An overly expansionary monetary policy harbors dangers. I consider all the concerns justified that there may be distortions of competition if bonds from large companies are bought on the capital market and the SMEs do not participate sufficiently. In addition, the ongoing low interest rate policy is putting a strain on the future of pension systems. Another problem is that longer-term savings rates in some Member States are below the respective inflation rate. On the other hand, the extraordinary actions of the ECB with the aim of raising the rate of inflation to 2% are to be welcomed. They are lawful, they are consistent with their mandate. Yes, there is no doubt that lending to households and businesses in the euro area has improved. However, the investments that should be achieved are not yet sufficient and are a whopping ten points below the pre-crisis level. These critical remarks, as well as some of the concerns raised by the rapporteur, enjoy broad support in the Report from Tremosa i Balcells.I thank Ramon on behalf of the EPP Group for his work and for his willingness to compromise, as well as for the constant cooperation with us shadow rapporteurs.I hope that tomorrow we can find a clear majority together - despite all the differences.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to thank Mr Mann, because he mentioned how important small and medium-sized businesses are, and also the promotion of self-employment.Last week we earmarked EUR 500 million in the European budget for 2017 for youth employment.I believe that small and medium-sized businesses in particular could play a much better role here.Mr Mann, do you see opportunities for the ECB to come up with a strategy for promoting employment among young people and self-employment and doing more for SMEs in order to focus the financing options here and see that SMEs are capableto create venture capital together with small and medium-sized banks?

name: Thomas MANN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.I can only agree with Mr Rübig.The European Parliament has given many special facilities to support SMEs.That is exactly what we need.What is the heart of the European economy?Small and medium-sized companies!Most apprenticeships and most jobs - that's exactly what we need. And that also has to sharpen the sense of the European Central Bank to ensure that we cannot say: We only work with the big ones, with the big companies, with themMajor banks.Mr Ramon has already pointed out how important it is to ensure that the others also receive support.We really have to work flat out on that.This is where results have to arrive and not just big declarations of intent.I absolutely agree with Paul Rübig.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the work of the rapporteur, our colleague Tremosa, in these months and that of all the shadow rapporteurs who have written and worked on this report, which I believe is a balanced document, which helps to understand the work of the ECB's monetary policy, but which also shines a bright light on where that monetary policy should be headed. Probably this report, as I was saying, clearly supports the main measures that the ECB has been taking aimed at achieving the inflation target, which is the main purpose of the European Central Bank. Because we really are still far from the goal, even with all the expansionary measures we have taken, and, therefore, we encourage and, somehow, illuminate some ways to improve access to credit for SMEs, as one of our colleagues said that they spoke previously: how small and medium-sized companies could also have a place within the monetary expansion programs of the ECB. But the report also clearly says that monetary policy alone does not work, that it is true that we need to carry out structural reforms in some sectors, and mainly in banking, because European banking, and in some countries putting greater difficulties, continues to restrict the ability to that the credit reaches all the companies and all the consumers. But apart from that reform, we need a serious fiscal policy. In the next few days we will see the annual growth report prepared by the Commission, and here is Commission Vice-President Dombrovskis, who must shed light on what fiscal policy should be. This fiscal policy has to clearly accompany monetary policy, because when rates are so low, when private investors have no certainty about their profitability because growth forecasts are very low, because really the environment in which Europe is operating is a very uncertain environment, we need the public sector to do its job. And, therefore, we need the public sector, which is ultimately the one who bears the risks in a society, to be able to boost demand to also facilitate the fulfillment of the inflation target by the European Central Bank. And therefore, in the coming months, within the framework of the European Semester as well, we will have to define what that policy should be, which does not just have to be a country-by-country approach, but there has to be a holistic approach to the policy. macro, of fiscal policy, which accompanies the monetary policy implemented by the European Central Bank, with a reasonable result in a very complex environment, as I said before. In any case, these last seconds I would like to dedicate to continue insisting on the need for the benefits of the European Central Bank, that the benefits of the only federal institution, the institution of the Union's currency, which is the euro, return to the budget of the Union as a whole. And this debate can be carried forward, it can be carried out without the need for an aggravated reform of the Treaties, and we should discuss it at some point in the coming months.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Madam President, first and foremost let me apologise for this delay, which was due to transport problems. I am happy to be back at the European Parliament to discuss with you the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2015. This debate is an important pillar of our accountability. We take your comments and suggestions very seriously. At your request, last year, we began publishing the ECB’s feedback on your resolution on the ECB Annual Report. On 4 October 2016, the Governing Council also approved principles increasing transparency in developing ECB regulations on European statistics. These principles take into account the transparency practices of the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the Commission. In my remarks today, I will retrace the economic developments since our last plenary exchange in February. In particular, I will discuss the role of the ECB’s monetary policy in supporting the ongoing recovery. I will also review the policy agenda aimed at addressing current vulnerabilities in the euro area. Let me say a few words now about economic developments and the role of the ECB’s monetary policy in supporting the recovery. The euro area recovery continues to proceed at a moderate but steady pace. It has shown remarkable resilience to adverse developments and uncertainties emanating from the global environment. In fact, euro area unemployment has been steadily declining. More than four million jobs have been created since 2013, when the situation was at its worst. Domestic demand has also strengthened and positive figures for real GDP growth have been recorded for 14 consecutive quarters. Since the beginning of the year, headline inflation has gradually picked up, moving from the negative rate of -0.2% in February to +0.5% in October. Our monetary policy measures since June 2014 have been a key factor behind these positive developments. Asset purchases, targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs, as they are called) and low policy rates have strongly supported the recovery. Let me explain more in detail. First, the pass-through of our monetary stimulus to bank lending conditions has been remarkable. Interest rates have fallen markedly across a broad spectrum of asset classes and credit markets since June 2014. As a result, euro area firms and households have experienced more favourable borrowing conditions. For example, bank lending rates for companies declined by more than 100 basis points between June 2014 and September 2016. Bank lending conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) – the backbone of our economy – have improved even more. Since May 2014, bank lending rates on very small loans to corporations have declined by around 170 basis points. They are now converging towards those on loans to large-scale borrowers. Evidence from our bank-lending survey supports this picture. Banks report that our measures are contributing to more favourable terms and conditions on loans and are supporting credit creation. Moreover, we see that banks are passing on the very attractive funding conditions of the TLTROs to their customers. Lower borrowing costs for firms and households have stimulated both consumption and investment. For example, household income is benefiting from lower interest-rate expenses. Likewise, investment spending benefits from lower financing costs, which are making more investment projects profitable. Supported by our monetary policy, the recovery is sustaining its momentum. We also expect headline inflation to continue rising over the coming months. At the same time, we are not seeing a consistent strengthening of underlying price dynamics. Much of the expected increase will be driven by statistical factors related to the stabilisation of oil prices. Moreover, the return of inflation towards our objective still relies on the continuation of the current, unprecedented level of monetary support, in spite of the gradual closing of the output gap. It is for this reason that we remain committed to preserving the very substantial degree of monetary accommodation necessary to secure a sustained convergence of inflation towards levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. However, as your draft resolution on our Annual Report argues, our monetary policy support has to be accompanied by decisive action from other policy areas. In fact, we continue to face a number of structural challenges that are holding back a more dynamic expansion of the euro area economy. So the right policies need to be designed to address existing vulnerabilities and challenges and, ultimately, to secure higher sustainable growth for the euro area. As I argued before, the euro area economy has proved resilient despite the uncertainty caused, among other things, by the crisis in emerging market economies, the collapse in oil and commodity prices, and the consequences of the UK referendum. Beyond the relevance of the ECB’s monetary policy, an important contributing factor has been the more robust financial sector which has emerged from the financial crisis. The decision to address the mistakes of the pre-crisis era through ambitious regulatory reforms is thus paying off. It has resulted in a European financial sector that is now stronger in terms of capital, leverage, funding and risk-taking. For example, Common Equity Tier 1 ratios in the euro area have improved substantially, rising from less than 7% for significant banking groups in 2008 to more than 14% today. The welcome improvements in bank solvency – and the related improvement in asset quality – are a tangible result of our common work to create the Banking Union. The comprehensive assessment we conducted in 2014 – together with a deep asset quality review – encouraged banks to strengthen their balance sheets without delay. As a result, while the level of non-performing loans (NPLs) remains high in some countries, today this problem is not primarily related to the robustness of balance sheets. Coverage ratios are close to 50% and much of the remainder is collateralised. A more resilient euro area banking system has been able to respond to the impetus originated by our monetary policy and facilitate the recovery in credit we have witnessed so far. However, a number of structural factors are still weighing on the ability of the financial sector to fully support the euro area recovery. Notably, the profitability of euro area banks remains a challenge to be addressed. While bank profitability and the level of bank equity prices is not, per se, a matter for policymakers, insofar as it raises financing costs for banks, it could ultimately curtail lending to the real economy and hold back the recovery. We should therefore consider what factors are behind this and what we can do to address them. One factor is certainly the low-growth and low-inflation environment, which translates into low interest rates. By supporting the recovery, our monetary policy measures are supporting a return towards higher rates of return. In other words, low interest rates today are necessary for a return to higher interest rates in the future. But legacy and structural challenges are also important factors behind banks’ low profitability. Where profitability is being affected by structural issues, such as overcapacity and inefficient cost structures, rationalisation and consolidation must form part of the answer. Where the non-performing loans (NPLs) are at a high level, creating the conditions for a faster resolution of bad loans is an essential part of the solution. ECB Banking Supervision has presented its draft guidance on NPLs for public consultation. We have also conducted a stocktake of national supervisory practices and legal frameworks related to NPLs. With a view to creating liquid markets of distressed debt, efforts will be required to foster the development of an NPL servicing industry, to improve data quality and access, and to remove tax and legal impediments to debt restructuring. The European Parliament also has an important role to play in a number of key legislative dossiers. Some relate to the Banking Union, with the proposed European Deposit Insurance Scheme and the introduction of ‘risk-reduction’ measures in the context of the upcoming revision of the legislative pillars of the Single Rulebook for banks – namely the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD), the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD). Others relate to the Capital Markets Union (CMU). In particular, the negotiations concerning the Securitisation Regulation need to be finalised soon. Securitisation can play a very important role in increasing bank funding to the economy but regulatory uncertainty is detrimental to European securitisation markets. We consider that the Commission has put forward a strong package that balances a revival of the European securitisation markets with the preservation of a prudent regulatory framework. Progress needs to be made in other areas too, in particular insolvency law and taxation, as announced in the Commission’s communication. It will also be necessary to address the financial stability aspects of CMU as part of the macroprudential review. A stable, profitable and competitive financial sector is essential for sustainable economic growth; but the reverse is also true. This is why we need more decisive action to raise the potential growth rate of the economy. First, let me echo your draft resolution. The implementation of structural reforms needs to be substantially stepped up. This concerns, in particular, policy actions to raise productivity and improve the business environment. We will soon discuss the Annual Growth Survey 2017, which touches upon these exact issues. We should make the best use of the annual cycle of economic governance by ensuring that recommendations – including euro area recommendations – are really taken into account and effectively implemented. Second, fiscal policies should also support the economic recovery, while remaining in compliance with the fiscal rules of the European Union. For instance, a more growth-friendly composition of fiscal policies could boost growth. This leads me to my concluding point. During our last plenary exchange in February, I said that the cohesion of Europe was being tested. Since then, the challenges have increased. It is now, more than ever, important and necessary that Europe responds cohesively and decisively to the challenges it is facing. I believe we should remember the words of a great European, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, spoken in this room more than ten years ago: ‘If we act alone we will be at the mercy of events bigger than us, events that threaten peace and European security.’ I am confident that the foundations on which the EU project is built are strong enough to achieve the objectives that have been entrusted to us by the people of Europe. I am now looking forward to the debate.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur very much for his report. And I would like to thank Mr Draghi for doing me the honor of appearing in the European Parliament just in time for my speech. I am also delighted, Mr Draghi, that you have said that you want to take what I am saying in my speech very seriously. Because the euro, Mr Draghi, is still in a serious crisis. And if you want to know how grave this crisis is, all you have to do is read this report that Mr Tremosa i Balcells wrote. He points out exactly the difficulties that exist in the euro area. It has already been stated several times in this debate that there is a great deal not right economically and fiscally in the eurozone. Despite all the measures that the European Central Bank has taken, we have nothing but distortions in the markets. But we have not made any progress in terms of productivity and competitiveness. We now have negative interest rates. And, Mr Draghi, you praise it by saying: Now households have more money to spend because they no longer have to pay so much interest. But the truth is that you are destroying a culture of saving and that with negative interest rates you are promoting a culture of debt. And that's the opposite of what we need. As has been stated, they are destroying private pension provision. Mr Draghi, in the 1990s I took out pension insurance for myself, for which the insurance company promised me a 4% guaranteed interest rate. How is this poor insurance company supposed to generate 4% guaranteed interest if you push interest rates into the zero range or even into the negative range? And at the same time we have these distortions, and at the same time we see the mortgage bubbles, the real estate bubbles, carried out by Mr. Tremosa i Balcells.We see rents rising in the big cities, we see the increase in inequality between those who have wealth, whose assets soar, and those who do not.I am really not on the left in this House, but, Mr Draghi, these are distributional effects that we really did not want as a result of central bank policy.One last word on the debate that has taken place within the EPP: the European Central Bank is not a ministry for the economy and it is not responsible for reducing youth unemployment.I strongly disagree.The European Central Bank has a mandate, and that mandate is monetary policy.And it cannot do more than monetary policy.But unfortunately she has exceeded this mandate by far.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, President Draghi, dear Ramon! Nothing is good in the euro area, especially not for the unemployed young people in Portugal, Greece or Spain that Mr Lucke mentioned. After the crisis, the USA implemented an expansive fiscal policy and recapitalized banks under state control. In Europe, banks have been bailed out for free and public investments, wages and pensions have been cut. The ECB has therefore missed its inflation target for years. The cheap money ends up in the financial markets, not in the real economy, because banks hardly grant loans because of bad papers and insufficient investment. The repackaging of scrap loans via the Capital Markets Union is absurd, however, because it is not about the middle class, it is about sweeping the bad papers off the balance sheets and passing them on like hot potatoes. But financial stability and growth are not a contradiction in terms. It was the financial crisis that brought us a lost decade. Deutsche Bank continues to be the most dangerous bank in the world, Italian banks have significant problems, and insurers are also a systemic risk. That is why we need public investment to normalize interest rate policy. It was just a mistake to force so many people into private old-age provision. We therefore need tough structural reforms for banks instead of pensioners or employees. The German megabank must be split up. The ECB has to support public investments because the German government continues to violate the rules of the game with its current account surpluses of 8% of GDP. The blackmail, the turning off of the euro, when governments - as in Greece - do not want to cut wages and pensions, is incompatible with the mandate of the ECB and must be stopped immediately.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Mr Draghi, welcome to Parliament. First of all, let me thank the rapporteur for the report for the work he has done. It is true that you, Mr Draghi, have had to face a situation of absolute paralysis on the part of the Member States, of an absolutely suicidal austerity policy, and it is you who have been forced to maintain a line of salvation , a lifeline for European economies through the development of unconventional policies. Obviously, that has not been enough for you to reach the inflation target set by the European Central Bank itself, which, I believe - we have said that many times in this House - that with the time that we have not reached that level inflation rate (2%), perhaps the Council should start to review it, since it has the power to do so. But it is true that you have been faced with fiscal inaction. And we see with concern - and my group is also concerned - that, after the European Commission's proposal to have a somewhat expansive fiscal policy next year - a little more than this year's fiscal position - the reaction of some Member States it has been to say "no" from the start; not only that of the German federal government but, surprisingly, also of the Spanish economy minister - surprisingly, I mean, because it would be one of the countries that would be most interested. And that is the situation that you have had to face and, from this point of view, I believe that the Member States bear a great deal of responsibility for the situation we are in. It seemed to me to understand that, in the medium term, you consider that the stimuli should not be withdrawn. Some member of the Governing Council has also said it this week. My group shares that - it seems to us to be premature. But I also have to tell you that the monetary stimuli have generated certain risky situations that are very worrying and that you cannot delay in facing them. It is evident that we have - there are many studies that point to this - problems with the impact that unconventional measures can have on inequality because, obviously, holders of financial assets benefit from the implicit subsidies that their policy implies in relation to the banking, implicit subsidies to large corporations. We had the opportunity to discuss that in the last appearance in the Economic Commission: you are buying bonds from large corporations that do not need help. It would be much more interesting if, together with, for example, the European Investment Bank, channels were created so that quantitative expansion could directly finance certain social and environmental projects, something that is installed in the public debate and that is extremely positive. Property bubbles have also been mentioned, I think it is also an obvious risk. And then, there is another thing that I want to talk to you about and that concerns us especially, which also has to do with the Bank's democratic control: it seems to us that in some of its instruments, you, as the Governing Council, have such discretion in apply the rules that has become a real democratic problem. And since we are - because this report is from 2015 - I have to talk about the emergency liquidity line, in which you, in even situations, have applied totally different policies and decisions. In the case of Cyprus, being the bank insolvent, the regulator saying that the bank was insolvent, you decided to maintain the emergency liquidity line, and in the case of Greece, on the other hand, without having said the supervisor that the bank was insolvent , you decided to cut it. Why? To this day, no one knows yet. And now I have to tell you that these kinds of things damage the credibility of the European Central Bank.They should clarify the rules of the emergency liquidity line.It seems to me a central question because, if not, the democratic credibility of the bank is at stake.I also say this because in the case of Greece - and since we are in 2015, it must also be said - the decisions that you took many times were too parallel to the decisions taken by the Eurogroup.And that too, somehow, put the Bank's reputation as an independent entity at risk.I believe that these things are lessons from which we have to learn and I hope, in any case, that many of the concerns that unconventional monetary policy measures generate today will be addressed and solved.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am a little disappointed, as every year, by the European Central Bank report because we miss a great opportunity to highlight, with a little intellectual honesty, what the economic and monetary situation is. We are witnessing a failure for European citizens, which is evident, because in terms of employment and in terms of economic development we have been at a standstill for several years, facing great deals for those who are currently buying the Member States at a discount price. . This is because, obviously, thanks to the policies applied through the euro and through the intrinsic austerity that exists in this project, there are cuts in public investments, wage devaluations to compensate for the system's inability to be able to balance imbalances existing, because we have blocked exchange rates and therefore wages are devalued and the policies of the jobs act simply imply making people poorer to make the Eurozone competitive. Here, this is a project that objectively cannot work in these terms and obviously those who want to speculate and privatize everything that is state property take advantage of it. And for this reason it is an unsustainable and also unreformable project. The euro zone will never be an optimal currency space, precisely because there are no prerequisites: if we go to read the books of all the greatest economists in the world, including Stiglitz, we realize how this cannot be proposed as a project. Therefore, there cannot be a single monetary policy for 19 countries and not even for 27 or 28, when the conditions are not right for it. And why? Because there are different needs in terms of interest rates and inflation rates. This is a problem that the euro and the ECB will never be able to solve and we, by not including it in this relationship, miss a great opportunity because the dissolution of the currency area is now at doors.We do not talk about it but this event will occur and most likely will happen in an uncontrolled way and it will be the fault of politics, which did not want to address this issue when it could face it.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Mr President, criticism of the ECB's policy is ever increasing in this Parliament. You must now take the plunge and denounce the very legitimacy of your monetary institution. Once again, it is announced that your 1.5 trillion money creation plan (quantitative easing) will now be extended until September 2017. Your credo is to always buy more securities and debt to save financial markets and European private banks in difficulty, but nothing is being done to revive the productive economy in the euro area. The straitjacket of your "single euro currency" forces economies to undergo an aberrant monetary policy which is anything but optimal, since all rates are divergent in the euro zone. This is economic heresy and some savvy economists even call you an arsonist. European countries must be given back control of their monetary tool so that they adapt the parity of their currency to the characteristics and needs of their national economy. The UK does, as does Switzerland. We must also give back to European countries the supervision of their national banking system. In short, we must return to national economic governance "whatever the cost", to use your expression. To have a recovery in economic activity, Germany must be convinced to use its budgetary margins to revive the demand engine. Ultimately, don't forget, Mr. Draghi, that if you don't want the peoples to overthrow Europe, you have to announce very quickly that you are transforming the single euro into a common currency, that is to say the ecu.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Madam President, the quantitative easing of the European Central Bank is the other side of the European Union's unpopular policy. It finances banking and other monopoly groups with plenty of money to boost capitalist growth. Any reduction in unemployment that you are referring to, Mr Draghi, means a generalization of flexible work. Competition within the European Union over the European Central Bank's management mix and monetary policy is not in the public interest, but in business groups trying to strengthen their position to the detriment of their competitors in the field of anemic growth in eurozone and the European Union. The Greek government's premise to close the second assessment, to extract a form of debt extension and to join the measures of the European Central Bank presupposes new barbaric anti-popular measures, possibly, and a fourth memorandum in Greece. But the debt's owes to the capitalists and not to the people. By fighting, the people, in conflict with their monopolies, power and imperialist unions, can become the owners of the wealth they produce.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, President Draghi, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I think that this report is very rich in content, contrary to what some colleagues underlined. I also think that its main message, at least from my point of view, is that we probably are at a turning point. Timid recovery fails to gather momentum. It is true that the political events of the past months have not helped to foster confidence and stability. It is true that monetary policy has done a lot to preserve and enhance this fragile growth, but it seems that unconventional monetary policy is reaching its limits, and the ECB has in fact been in charge of coping with most parts of the post-crisis adjustment. As President Draghi stressed earlier this year, half of the growth we have witnessed is due to the exceptional monetary policy that has been put in place. But this alone cannot solve the problem of imbalances; it cannot solve the problem of huge debt overhang. The quantitative easing seems to blur the line between monetary and fiscal policy. It might not be stimulating other adjustments – fiscal and structural – needed to resolve impediments to put the economy on a more robust growth path.  We also know that even though this policy’s benefits have so far outweighed the costs, there are negative side effects to it which are well outlined in the report. Whatever it takes in terms of ECB action, I hope that it does not make the leaders continue to think ‘why should we bother?’ We must continue to emphasise that the last bell is indeed ringing for fiscal policy, for public investment and for private investment to take it over. I also believe that the proposals in the context of the Capital Markets Union look very promising as tools stimulating growth policy.  The results of some studies also suggest that monetary policy might no longer be able to be the same in the future, with real interest rates lower than in the decades preceding the crisis. Whatever it will be, monetary policy will remain fundamentally important for the eurozone in the future, and the ECB will continue to be on the front line. There are still many black swans out there ready to test our cohesion and resilience. Therefore, let me finish by saying very strongly that we must avoid anything that could cause a loss of confidence in the monetary policy of the European Central Bank.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, Mr President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for being here. Basically, the examination of the annual report of the Central Bank is also the moment to take stock of the balance of the European policy mix and this is indeed the direction of the debate which has just started. Mr President, you have said how much this unconventional policy of the Central Bank had made it possible to support the activity of the Union and, as you know, this Parliament, with the report by Mr Tremosa i Balcells, supports the maintenance of this unconventional activity of your bank in order to support both demand and the return of inflation in Europe. But, for all that, including on the monetary side, it is clear that a certain number of things still need to be examined and improved. First, the issue of non-performing loans. At some point, I think we will have to ask ourselves whether, beyond the work done by supervisors, we need or not a framework for European reflection or action. Regarding my second question, you once again mentioned the overcapacity, the need for rationality or the insufficiencies in terms of profitability in the banking sector. It is a track on which you now regularly insist and on which we will have to come back. Finally, you mentioned the issue of banking union. We would like to ask you not to lose confidence and to continue to plead with us in favor of this EDIS (European deposit guarantee system), but also in favor of the final backstop of the second pillar because, otherwise, we are well aware that the significant steps that have been taken will be weakened. There is one element in the international context that you did not mention - so I would gladly do so - which is the question of the election of Donald Trump in the United States and the impact that will have in terms of evolution of interest rates. I'm sure your institution is there prepares, but we also need, on the European side, to have visibility on how this will or will not impact the European economy.Beside you - you always say this - you need governments to do the job.It is in this sense that we support one of the proposals that you also made in the report of the five presidents in favor of a budget for the euro zone.Here too, we need you to keep your strength of conviction to move forward.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - I have great confidence in the rapporteur, our Catalan colleague Ramon Tremosa. This report is going well, we are heading in the right direction. I have a lot less confidence in the promotional pitch we got here at the beginning of Mr. Draghi's speech. I sincerely think that people do not need such a European promotional talk. What they do need and what they are entitled to is explanation. They are entitled to an explanation of what the European institutions do. They are entitled to an explanation in plain language, in a language they understand, because I notice that not everyone today understands the consequences of your policy, Mr Draghi. Not everyone sees the consequences of your decision to print massive money from your extremely low interest rates. Yes, people see that their savings are no longer profitable, but do they also know that your policy is putting their pensions at risk? Do they also know that your policy is increasing inequality instead of decreasing it? Do they also know that your policies affect our productivity and that the purchasing power of people is also affected? We need to do something about that. We need to relearn what happens to people's money, because today they have to pay tuition fees mainly through your policies and your monetary games.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, Mr Draghi, Mr Dombrovskis, the doctrine of 'austerity, austerity, austerity' has failed. The eurozone needs a shift towards sustainable and strong growth, and it needs it now. This means, firstly, more investment and stimulating demand, especially in countries with high primary surpluses, such as Germany, which have fiscal space and with surpluses of 8% violate European conditions. Secondly, the completion of the banking integration, finally, with the creation of the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme and, thirdly, the extension of the quantitative easing program after March 2017 with the participation, finally, of my country, Greece, in it. Mr Dombrovskis and Mr Draghi, Greek men and women are living up to their commitments. They make big changes with huge sacrifices. But we feel that we have been living the myth of Sisyphus for years. It is time for you, the Commission, the European Central Bank, together with the Eurogroup, to live up to your commitments on 5 December for both debt relief and quantitative easing.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, each time Mario Draghi visits this Parliament I eagerly look forward to it. He tells us how well the eurozone is functioning and how strongly the economic recovery on the European continent is going along. Nothing could be further from the truth. The macroeconomic forecasts about growth, productivity and employment rates are painfully low. In 2015 the youth unemployment rate in Greece, Spain and Italy was reaching levels of 40% to 50%. The gap between the countries in the North and the South of the eurozone is becoming even bigger. Only naive euro-federalists believe that the euro is good for the citizens and that the euro project is creating wealth and economic growth.  Mario Draghi and his European Central Bank are ruining this continent. Mr Draghi, you still believe, with your unconventional monetary policy, that you are stabilising the economy. But, in reality, you are creating massive financial bubbles that will burst sooner or later and will trigger a new financial crisis. As a consequence, the political groups in this House that are still supporting the crazy monetary policy of the ECB are taking a monstrous responsibility. It was the libertarian philosopher Ayn Rand who wrote, ‘You can avoid reality, but you cannot ignore the consequences of avoiding reality’. Even the former EU Commissioner Frits Bolkestein, who created the internal market, said last weekend in the Dutch and Flemish press that the euro will die in the next few years, and he is right. We in Great Britain do not want your fairy-tale politics any longer. That is the reason why, as Great Britain never wanted to join the euro project, we are now leaving. Great Britain has had enough of the single market and that is the reason why we will leave the European Union – the sooner the better. Scotland will go with us too, despite the fantasies of our First Minister.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - The ECB is perhaps the only central bank in the world, and perhaps even in history, to have become such a political body to such an extent. It is perhaps the only central bank that has extended its mandate to become a de facto political body, but without any democratic control, which is perhaps the intention behind all of this. That evolution is logical. Where a normal central bank is an instrument of a political government, the central bank operates in the euro zone, a zone that actually has no political authority. It operates in a zone where political authority is somehow reconstructed or the appearance of it is created by a stability pact, a European Semester, a banking union, a deposit insurance scheme and the like. In this way they try to compensate for the fact that in that eurozone, in the European Union, there is no political authority with which one could justify a unity of a currency. Keeping that vehicle on track, along with all the money you put into it, along with the funds that go for it, a vehicle that is doomed to crash from the start, keeping that track is the phase in which we now find ourselves with an ECB that has become increasingly part of the political mandate it has given, which it has actually given itself. The promise to "do whatever is necessary", the quantitative easing, the buying up of securities or worthless papers, the powers of attorney, the special powers that the ECB uses without having to fear much more scrutiny: this is a situation that the scares citizens. Inflation would be stimulated, but this has led to deflation. Growth would be stimulated, but there is virtually a growth stop that entails all the risks that the debt bubble you created yourself would explode. The people's lack of confidence is something we can fully understand.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, in 2015 the Greek people lost their confidence in the European Union and realized the hypocrisy of the Left. With the "no" in the referendum of July 2015, he clarified that he radically disagrees with the economic policies of the Union. Ensuring the viability of the euro has led to unemployment, business destruction, poverty and misery. The referendum order, however, was not implemented by the left-wing Tsipras government. Thus the financial pressure of the European Central Bank and the inhuman attitude of the Commission have trampled on the dignity of a proud people. This report confirms the crisis of the Greeks. They urgently need to adopt a new economic policy and a new model of development, a bold debt cut through a significant reduction in its nominal value, an immediate cessation of austerity measures and the fight against bank speculation and corruption of political and economic actors. Simply put, we need nationalist governments, and I'm just glad that the people showed their intentions with Brexit and the election of Trump in the United States. Austria and France will follow, of course.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - First of all, of course, I would like to thank all my colleagues who made it possible for us today to have a report here that really focuses on the functioning of the central bank itself and not on the Union's financial policy, as we have seen in the past. The main theme of the euro area in 2015 was economic recovery, although unfortunately this is still not the same in all countries. Some succeeded more, others a little less. In addition, as has been repeatedly pointed out, we are plagued by low inflation and very low interest rates. This, of course, is a very big cause for concern. We all emphasize this. This policy has produced results, but it does not necessarily continue to produce them. If these measures are not combined with some other measures, then we cannot hope for success. I am pleased that we are dealing with this report relatively quickly already this calendar year. And what we need to emphasize, and we all emphasize: that, in addition to these monetary measures, we also need structural measures. Economic growth, which has also been helped by central bank measures, may have put us to sleep a little too much, and some countries are now not making enough effort to make much-needed structural reforms, especially in the area of ​​pensions, in the face of such low economic growth. The demographic situation will not be better tomorrow, but it will be worse. It is precisely because of such a policy pursued by the European Central Bank that our pension funds are also in danger. However, I would like to point out one more thing: the European Central Bank can, of course, influence the credibility of all the microsystems we have in Europe through its actions, within its competences. We have not done our homework everywhere and in many countries, including my country Slovenia, we are still dealing with the consequences of rescuing the banking system, caused either by deliberately fraudulent acts or not by entrepreneurial ... non-entrepreneurial activities. I am therefore pleased that Mr Draghi also spoke about the draft guidelines for bad loans. I hope we come up with a step forward.And, of course, my colleagues in Slovenia are working very hard to find those responsible for the perpetrators of the banking holes, and I hope that they will have more or at least good support from the European Central Bank.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - Madam President, Mr President Draghi, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, with this report the European Parliament expresses its support for the ECB's monetary policy action, recognizing that the measures implemented are consistent with its mandate, with the aim price stability and, in this way, with that of contributing to the more general economic policy of the Union. It is hardly contestable that, in the face of the unprecedented scenario of low growth, low inflation, low level of the natural interest rate, the extraordinary monetary policy measures implemented by the ECB were decisive in preserving the euro area from deflation and contributing to the economic recovery in progress. To those who wonder about their risks and their negative implications, it is good to remember that the monetary policy of the ECB is not the cause of low interest rates but is the symptom and the necessary - if not the only - therapy. Given the moderate pace of the recovery and its exposure to the downside risks deriving from the current phase of political and economic uncertainty, it is clear that a continuation of the current expansionary nature of monetary policy will be necessary to ensure a return of the inflation rate. below, but close, at 2%. At the same time, it is equally clear that this action, while necessary, is not enough. We must therefore make better and stronger use of the economic policy instruments we have. We are facing the risk of a vicious circle between expectations of low growth and low investments, which can also have a negative impact on potential growth, making the effect of the crisis structural and not just cyclical. This scenario is aggravated by the uncertainties of the political framework and by the possible pursuit of a line of economic unilateralism by the new American administration. For this it is necessary to make our policy a more growth-oriented mix of structural reforms and fiscal policies, in particular by supporting public and private investment and strengthening social and territorial cohesion.In this sense, the Commission's recommendation of a moderately expansionary fiscal stance constitutes an important step forward which now needs to be translated into concrete actions and instruments.The European Parliament will not fail to have its voice in this debate.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President!I am glad that the report presents a moderately critical approach by the European Parliament to the response to the ECB report, especially as regards maintaining negative interest rates.In my opinion, however, this is not enough.I cannot vote in favor of a report that accepts and welcomes the ECB's policy of defending the euro at all costs, using such unconventional means as, among other things, an asset purchase program.I would simply call it printing money.I am also concerned about the call to complete the banking union and the capital markets agreements, which, in short, pose a serious threat not only to countries in the euro area.I am surprised that this is not the case.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, Mr Draghi! We're talking about the ECB's annual report, and it's all about your statement from August 2012: "What ever it takes." that you are ready to break anything. Our former constitutional judge Kirchhof put it in a nutshell and said: "An instability of the law outweighs an instability of the finances." Mr. Draghi, you have illegally and unlawfully expanded the mandate of the ECB. You make politics. You want to do labor market policy and you want to prevent Italy or Greece from leaving the euro. You make politics. But you have no mandate to do so. You have no right to do so, it is not your job to make politics. And what's more: nothing in life is free. Someone will pay for your policy: it will be the savers who will no longer get interest. It will be the health insured whose benefits will be reduced and it will be the people with life insurance who will need interest in order to have something in old age. Nothing is free in life. You won't pay the price. But it's the little ones who will pay the price. It's the little ones. That is why your policy is not only wrong and illegal, it is above all anti-social. Stop doing that.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Madam President, Mr Draghi! There is one sentence that I keep hearing from the entire EU camarilla, but which I can no longer hear: “The Commission has presented a very good paper.” It has presented a paper that shows the macroeconomic imbalance Indicates the rise in debt in the euro countries, the decline in investment, the asset bubble and its social consequences - despite all the measures you have taken. Or, Mr Draghi, perhaps precisely because of the measures you have taken? Public finance: illegal, corporate finance: illegal, now also the financing of SMEs - yes, that too: illegal. Mr Draghi, at some point you may also finance private individuals, that too would be illegal. Incidentally, you are now engaged in politics in all areas of economic and social policy - including illegally, outside your mandate, Mr Draghi. You mentioned that we might become the pawn of events bigger than us. Mr. Draghi, math is bigger than us, and debts you want to build up are inherent in the system. It's a pyramid game. You only have the choice between deflationary spiral or hyperinflation. You will have to choose, Mr Draghi. This is fraud against the citizen, fraud against savers, fraud against future retirees and the working middle class, Mr Draghi. The longer you continue your destructive work, the more dramatic the consequences will be for the citizens of the Euro Prison. Stop it! Stop creating these social upheavals!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, Mr Mário Draghi, the first thing we must recognize in this debate is that the monetary policy of the European Central Bank has made an important contribution, not only to defend the euro, to stabilize debt markets sovereignty, give an opportunity to the European economy and counter deflationary pressures. We must value this clearly. We all know that there may be collateral damage from an overly prolonged policy of negative interest. But voices calling for a precipitous retreat in monetary policy at this time, which is still a time of uncertainty and turbulence, and which could become, after Brexit and the new Trump administration, a time of uncontrolled financial speculation in the sovereign debt markets. What we expect from the European Central Bank is a message of stabilizing markets, a message of decisive intervention to guarantee the integrity of the euro area. I ask President Mário Draghi whether this remains the fundamental mission of the ECB at this historic moment in the European economy, when the euro is still under threat. This is very important for the entire eurozone, but also for the countries most threatened by speculation, such as Portugal. I would also like to ask you whether, after the results achieved on the economic and budgetary front, with the rating assessment, Portugal continues to be eligible for the European Central Bank's asset purchase program.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, again in the same work, viewers, as Mr Draghi insists on violent fiscal adjustment, the so-called anti-social reforms and the partial austerity that have filled Europe with armies of the unemployed. And although you, Mr Draghi, have spent over € 1.3 trillion on quantitative easing, unemployment remains high. All you have to do is create a huge debt bubble with the money of European taxpayers, buying mainly German bonds worth 250 billion euros. In fact, not only do you not give a single cent to Greece through the quantitative easing, but you forced the Bank of Greece to participate in the quantitative easing in 2015 with 17 billion euros, that is, instead of writing off the Greek debt, you forced Greece to lend to lenders of. At the same time you are giving the red loans to the crows and you continue, Mr Draghi, to be in the troika illegally, even though there is a decision to expel them from the Court of Justice of the European Union. So when will you leave the troika, Mr Draghi? When will you stop the conflict of interest within the ECB, since the ECB cannot be both a member of the troika and a lender and a supervisor and a supposedly independent monetary authority? You cannot, Mr Draghi, wear four hats at the same time. Understand: an independent ECB does not mean an uncontrolled ECB.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mario Draghi, you said you were going to listen, you spoke about credibility, you spoke about legacy issues. Your credibility and the credibility of the ECB are intrinsically interlinked. In 2007, Jonathan Sugarman was risk manager at the UniCredit Bank in Ireland. That summer, Jonathan officially reported to the regulator in the Irish Central Bank a multi—billion—euro liquidity breach amounting to 20 times the permissible deviations. There was no sanction by the Central Bank and the breaches continued, forcing Sugarman to resign. In February 2010, Irish Finance Minister Brian Lenihan stated that the financial regulator maintains close communications with the regulator of other Member States. In 2007 you were the Governor of Banca d’Italia, with UniCredit the biggest bank on your watch. You spoke about transparency. Answer this: can you please confirm whether you were informed by the Central Bank of Ireland of these multi—billion—euro breaches at UniCredit Dublin? If so, can you explain why that bank has never been sanctioned, and now that you know this what are you going to do about it? You spoke about the cohesion of Europe being tested. You are testing it. Answer this question, otherwise you test it further. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – A very, very, good speech, Mr Flanagan, as always. I just wanted to know. You and I were concerned before about whether Mr Draghi had appeared before the Irish Parliament and the committees of the Irish Parliament. Did that ever happen? Could you enlighten us all?

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card answer. – We were told that Mr Draghi was answerable to the European Parliament. Unfortunately, whenever I make any attempt to ask him this question at the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I am refused because apparently I am not a member. I am a Member of this Parliament, and I am asking him now. People are waiting with baited breath: what did you know about this? We need an answer. People are watching, and we want one.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr. President, György Matolcsy would not be allowed close to the national banks in any European country, only Viktor Orbán can be the Governor of the Magyar Nemzeti Bank in Hungary. His criminal record is very long, just let me quote a few of it. He launched unorthodox economic training out of billions of taxpayers ’money. Billions of monuments, castles and overpriced office buildings were taken from our money. His cousin is constantly receiving money out of the pockets of Hungarian taxpayers in a suspicious way. Mr. Matolcsy is trying to outsource the money of the Magyar Nemzeti Bank to the foundations, saying that it will lose the character of public money. The last time we learned that he was hiring his own girlfriend was to pay a million, and at the same time, he lives in the luxury apartment of one of the heads of a commercial bank in Budapest. Everything stinks around György Matolcsy. They break the rules, scatter money back and forth, keep the forint weak and delay the introduction of the euro. György Matolcsy does not work to protect the money of the Hungarian people. That is why I am telling you, Mr Draghi, that we do not need to write reports on this matter, but because of open violations of European rules, and in order to protect the money of the Hungarian people, György Matolcsy must be screened immediately.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mr President, Mr Draghi! They say you know the risks of your policy. That has already been described here in the house - but there is nothing better. I draw your attention to two sets of economic logic. They demand that the structural reforms in the budgets of the nation states be increased. But if you pursue a zero interest rate policy, there is no longer any incentive to carry out structural reforms. Yes, your policies are downright preventing structural reforms. The second sentence is, as Mr Valli said: We have a wrong relative price within the monetary union: the undervaluation of the euro for Germany and the overvaluation of the euro for the south of the euro area. With your policy, you cannot get rid of this false relative price, even if you put on another trillion program. So let your staff calculate why unemployment is high in Portugal, in Greece, and why it has fallen to a record level in Germany! Take note of that. Otherwise, I tell you, the ECB is, so to speak, the executioner of the euro and the euro area.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, in the foreword to the 2015 report, the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, congratulated his bank on its success in boosting confidence in the future of businesses, citizens and banks in a shaky and global economy;across Europe.It seems to me, Director-General Draghi, that we live in different realities, because I see a continuing rise in European inequality and a belief in a future that does not belong to everyone, the continuing impoverishment of the poor and even the most important middle class, and the banks that are trustedgreed.You are talking about how the European Central Bank will act as an anchor for the faith of the future.Is this anchor stuck anywhere?

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think we have to thank the European Central Bank and the work of President Draghi, because in these times, in these years, they have given financial stability to our continent and the eurozone and because they have held this last sheltered from the severe financial storms that have occurred. But I - President Draghi don't like it - would like to make a reference on this occasion above all to politics, especially to you Commission and to us Parliament. I would like to refer to two responsibilities that we have as politicians. The first is that we must renew our institutions to give democratic control to our eurozone, democratic control to our budgets and our economy. The second reminder is that we must transform the work that has been done by the European Central Bank into policies: employment policies, growth policies, development policies, investment policies for our young companies and for the environment. We have to do it! In one sentence: we cannot continue to shift our responsibilities to the European Central Bank. We should leave the responsibility for monetary policy to the European Central Bank but we must have the courage to regain possession of economic policies, fiscal policies and social policies. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Marco VALLI
text: Question "blue card".- I listened with interest to the speech and since he said he wants the European Central Bank to deal with monetary policies, I want to understand how it is possible that a single monetary policy is good for 19 countries that right now show different needs interms of interest rates and inflation?How can this happen from both a political and, above all, technical point of view?Because technically today it is impossible.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I confess that, from a technical point of view, I leave the answer to the technicians.From the political point of view, which is what interests this Parliament the most, I believe that, as I said in my speech, either we are able to renew our institutions and thus make the eurozone democratic too, or, of course, notwe will be able to respond to the need you called which, however, I share.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the euro is primarily a political project that has made millions of people unhappy and badly shaken the Union's reputation in the eyes of its citizens. However, social dissatisfaction is easily overcome due to clear political goals. Monetary union can hardly function without fiscal union. She is next in line and then we will have the European Federation. That's the plan. It is therefore not surprising that the euro has so much support among European elites and that this report welcomes the European Central Bank's promise to do whatever it takes to defend the euro. The euro binds too many different economies that at the end of each business cycle, when a recession sets in, will find themselves in the same trouble as at the end of the last decade. The southern countries have a noose around their necks, and the northern ones end up pulling them out of the mud with money from their taxpayers, into which both are forced by the unrealistic ambitions of the European political class. It's time to come to our senses.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - The euro is a giant on feet of clay.From above, that statue with stainless steel from Luxembourg, Germany and the Netherlands still looks nice, but the more you descend, the more clay you encounter.Attempts have been made, Mr President, to strengthen that image, but strangely enough, this has been done by adding even more clay.For example, the maintenance of the crumbling structure has been totally neglected.Last week, heavily indebted countries were given further delay to implement reform measures.A disastrous decision, only made of clay.Inflation also remained irresponsibly low with numerous negative effects, for example for the pension funds.President elect Trump has already had a more favorable effect on inflation last month than the QE buy-back program of the European Central Bank in the past twenty months.The current approach to the problems in the eurozone increases the risk that the image of the euro will one day collapse with a thunderous blow.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, I would not like to be in your place.I believe you are lucid and obliged to hold a speech in which you no longer believe.The euro zone no longer functions, there are no comparative advantages, the North's surpluses no longer go to the South, it no longer makes sense.How to get out of it since, anyway, you are already illegal?The only thing that should have been done - and you can still do it, but will you do it?-, it would have been to proceed with a quantitative easing geared only to the countries of the South, to create money not to save a financial system, but to benefit the real economy, to truly profitable projects.This would not create counterfeit money like you are doing now.You have this chance, but if you don't seize it, you will historically be responsible for the crisis you have created.

text: NI). - Mr President, the monetary policy pursued by the European Central Bank so far has had the objective of rescuing the banks and the euro. In general, he achieved this goal. name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, today it is clear that the banking union, created to give strength to the financial system and to deal with systemic banks, dubbed "too big to fail", was nothing more than a maneuver designed to remove any possibility of intervention from the national public sphere and to impose a set of merger operations between financial institutions, thus aggravating the problem that it was supposed to solve. In the Portuguese case, the situation is stark. With the centralization of all supervisory and resolution functions at the ECB, the largest Portuguese banks ended up being sold to foreign groups at a bargain price, leaving the loss to the taxpayers, since the resolution fund has only been financed by the Portuguese State. As is evident, this banking union does not help to solve any of the problems of economies, with or without a deposit guarantee system, because this banking union is the expression of the dominance of the financial system over the political power of the European Union, which has long since resigned to defend citizens' interests to dedicate themselves to serving the interests of those who effectively rule Europe.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Thank you to the rapporteur for the report and also to the colleagues who, in their speeches, acknowledged to the Central Bank that it has done a demanding job recently, that in many areas, in resolving the euro, the economic situation in the countries has been addressed to some extent. stabilized and there are some signs of recovery within Europe.
