name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Draghi, lastly, in preparing the extension of quantitative easing beyond March, stated that we cannot let our guard down, as the economy is in a steady and moderate recovery but the fundamentals are still fragile and monetary policy remains a key ingredient for GDP recovery. name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me thank you all, but first and foremost the rapporteur, Ramon Tremosa i Balcells, for this debate. The ECB’s independence is a precondition for its effectiveness in safeguarding price stability. But so too is accountability, especially in difficult economic times, with monetary policy playing an important role in improving the financing to the real economy. To understand and debate monetary policy it is therefore essential for us to shoulder our part of the responsibility, first and foremost, as President Draghi has outlined, regarding the implementation of structural reforms. This debate thus perfectly sets the tone for the discussions which will be held tomorrow on the European Semester. It has demonstrated that there is much common ground between the Commission’s and the European Parliament’s views, so we count on your continued support in building the foundations for sustainable growth and job creation in Europe.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, let me thank Mr Tremosa i Balcells and his colleagues for the report. I would also like to thank Vice-President Dombrovskis, and let me thank all of you for the very relevant and useful debate, and also for the deep concerns that you have expressed on various issues and on the present situation.  Let me just present to you a few scattered observations. First of all, this is the first year when the GDP of the euro area has returned to the level of before the crisis. It has taken us seven and a half years. So if we look back, things are better today than they were before. That is the first statement of fact that we should collectively keep in mind. And all this in spite of the serious geopolitical risks that are maturing and have matured especially this year. Any available evidence suggests that the transmission of our accommodative monetary policy is effective. It has contributed, as I was saying before, to a significant easing in the borrowing conditions for firms and households – not for the large capitalists as such, but for everybody – and our policy has stimulated credit creation, and it is basically supporting the euro area recovery.  There are two surveys. One is the bank lending survey where we asked banks what they are doing with their credit conditions, and they all say they have expanded credit, they have expanded the standards and their costs have been going down considerably for a long time. Then we also asked the Commission for a survey for SMEs, and similar questions were asked revolving around how they felt today with respect to credit conditions. The answers are unambiguously positive. The annual rate of growth of loans to firms has increased from -3% to +2% since May 2014.  Some of your points, and also those in the draft resolution, raised the issue of heterogeneity within the euro area, along with some other points raised before. That also has improved as well. Development in lending rates to non—financial corporations point to a drastic reduction in the fragmentation of bank lending across the euro area, and I can give you all kinds of numbers about that. We have next to the Asset Purchase Programme for the public sector a programme – and it was referred to in some of the interventions – where we buy corporate sector bonds. One lingering worry is that this programme actually benefits large corporates and does not benefit SMEs. Nothing could be further from the truth. SMEs have actually improved their lending conditions a lot. There is one good reason for this, which is that if the large corporates borrow more on the capital markets they will free space in the banks’ balance sheets for SMEs. And, by the way, the corporate bond market has also experienced a significant increase in issuance. So funding costs and better access to finance have improved for both small and large companies, and this has and will have a positive effect on investment.  Having said that, I understand – from your words, of course, but also we are aware – that there are concerns as regards the risks associated with low interest rates and our unconventional measures. Our measures still entail some medium—term risks and have side effects. However, do we see a bubble today? If we look at asset valuations we do not see that their valuations are somewhat high or stretched. Also, any analysis would show that it is not a rise in asset prices per se that can create long-term damage to financial and macroeconomic stability, but it is an asset price boom which is fuelled by excess borrowing and leveraging, and this we do not have.  In summary, financial stability risks related to our monetary policy measures are for the time being contained, but we will certainly watch them closely, and we are certainly aware that they have to be observed and monitored very, very closely. But we should also be aware that the right macroeconomic policy is the best safeguard of financial stability. On the low interest rates let’s be clear: low interest rates are a consequence of low growth and low inflation all over the world. They are not the creation of the ECB. In this situation, as I was saying I think in my introductory remarks, the policy rates by the ECB have to be low in order to stimulate growth and when you have higher growth and higher inflation, the policy rates of the ECB will also increase. By and large so far, the negative rate situation, when we weigh up benefits and costs, we see that the benefits are bigger than the costs. Of course, there are many different considerations here, and you have all kinds of actors, but the impact of recent monetary policy measures on bank profitability so far has been contained. We are aware that this is not going to be forever. In the medium term, negative interest rates will certainly create a negative effect on banks’ profitability.  On the economic outlook, as I have communicated before, at our next monetary policy meeting in early December we will assess the inflation outlook and our monetary policy stance. Our assessment in December will benefit from the new staff projections extending up to 2019, and we will also take stock of the work of the eurosystem committees on the options that ensure a smooth implementation of our purchase programme until March 2017 or beyond, if necessary. We are committed to preserving an accommodative monetary policy stance that is necessary to bring inflation towards levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. And we are also committed to act if warranted by using all the instruments available within our mandate to achieve our objective. Of course, other policies should also play a role, and I have commented on these several times in the past.  Let me now address some of the points – unfortunately in quite a scattered way – but, first of all, our monetary policy is by and large similar to the monetary policy that has been pursued in the United States, in the United Kingdom and in Japan. The policies of the large central banks do not differ very much today. Second, the Troika. There isn’t any sentence by any court that forbids the ECB to be in the Troika. It is true that, over the years, in the last two or three years, the ECB has carved itself, in a sense, a much narrower role in the Troika, closer to our own specificity – namely the financial sector and the banking sector. It does not have as much of a voice as it used to in the past on the macroeconomic programmes, where it is the Commission which is the predominant voice. , I have already addressed the point that the large corporates benefit from our programmes while the SMEs do not. On our mandate, some of the statements were saying either explicitly or implicitly that we are overstepping our mandate. Well, we went to court and that is not the view of the European Court of Justice. Our policies generate inequality? That is not what the data shows. The creation of four million jobs has done more for reducing inequality than anything else. It is true that when the central banks’ buy assets, asset prices go up and the owners of the assets are usually wealthy, and you may have a worsening of distribution in the short term, but then the effect upon employment and upon economic activity reduces the major sources of inequality, which is unemployment, and that is what has happened in the euro area, where we have basically created four million jobs.  A point was raised on ELA which, by the way, is the prerogative of the national competent authorities – in this case, the national central banks of Cyprus and Greece – and this emergency liquidity assistance has to comply with the monetary financing prohibition laid down in Article 123 of the Treaty. So the ELA decisions have not violated any of these principles. They did not violate the Treaty and they were taken in a fair and uniform way across countries and across time.  On Ireland, we had a dedicated hearing on Ireland in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Policy and any MEP can ask us any question in writing and we always answer. So if there are questions about Ireland, on UniCredit and so on, please send us the question and we will answer it.  I think I have answered most of the questions. Some of you raised the point of what the consequence of the US elections will be on our outlook. It is really very difficult to assess what the impact of this change will be on our economic policy and on the economic outlook of the euro area, but in general – and we have seen this with the outcome of the UK referendum – we had a reaction in the markets in both cases which at the beginning was pretty significant, but then it became muted and markets have shown their resilience thanks also, especially in the first case, to the preparation of the Bank of England on the one side, and the European Central Bank on the other. But I do not think we should stop at that. Clearly these changes have a long-term impact which is very difficult to assess, and in the case of the UK it will depend on the shape of the final negotiation and the length of time it will take to find an agreement.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: relatore. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, caro presidente Draghi, benvenuto ancora una volta al Parlamento europeo. name: David Maria SASSOLI

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - The proposed report supports the unconventional monetary policy instruments adopted in the face of the ongoing financial crisis that originated in the US housing crisis. The far-reaching and best-known unconventional tool is quantitative easing (QE), which began in 2011. In 2015, the ECB expanded its program to QE and began with massive purchases of government bonds and bonds from private borrowers. Here the ECB used a loophole in its statute to buy massive amounts of government bonds on the secondary market. However, regardless of the partial economic successes of QE in Japan and the United States, it turns out that monetary policy also has limits. Because monetary policy alone cannot help overcome underlying structural, economic problems and inequalities. The problem with QE remains that states no longer feel any pressure to implement necessary structural reforms, which means that the signals from the European Commission, the Troika / Quadriga and the monetary policy environment are in contradiction to one another. However, a close link between fiscal and monetary policy is essential for successful crisis management. This poses major challenges for the euro area; decisions are certainly possible at Council level, but these objectives should be supported by the ECB through its monetary policy and not, as is now the case, indirectly undermined.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Olle Ludvigsson, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services (2016/2056 (INI)) (A8-0294 / 2016)

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the party groups, who have been very cooperative and enabled us to reach a broad consensus in an area that will become more important over time, namely how we can create the conditions for a single market for financial services. for individuals and small businesses. I would like to emphasize that I welcome the Commission's Green Paper. It has come at just the right time. Due to significant border barriers, cross-border trade in financial services is still undeveloped. It is bad for consumers, inhibiting for innovative companies and disrupting the functioning of the European economy. Therefore, we need to work to unleash the full potential of that market and support innovative solutions that can benefit consumers. A large part of the financial services today are linked to 28 different markets, which are characterized by low competition and a lack of global competitiveness. If the power of digitalisation is used properly, a European regulatory system can strengthen the individual consumer and contribute to a better financial product at lower prices. It is a golden opportunity that we must not miss. A larger part of the payments are now made digitally. Here we need a competition-neutral regulatory framework that ensures that new innovative players can continue to contribute to growth for more jobs in Europe. Legislation needs to ensure that increased competition contributes to real added value for consumers. The most basic rights for citizens, such as the right to open a bank account, need to be strengthened. The financial supervisory authorities need to better monitor how banks and other financial institutions comply with adopted, implemented acts such as PSD II, Mifid and the Money Laundering Directive. I am convinced that in times like these, the EU must concentrate on one of its core missions. We need to break down more barriers so that the free market can move promoted. Therefore, as soon as possible, the Commission needs to present a series of legislative proposals that take into account Parliament's views. A broad set of regulations for financial services within the Union is likely to be an important piece of the puzzle in achieving better mobility among EU citizens. Today, financial actors all too often condition private individuals' consumption of financial services with the requirement of permanent residence. A clear example is that credit cards stop working for some Europeans when they choose to move to another Member State. The Commission should therefore present proposals to address the problem of geoblocking, which is specifically linked to financial services trading. Another challenge is to make the identification work in practice. Today, there are major problems that can be linked to identification and digital financial services. Therefore, the technology for identification needs to be standardized. The interpretation of the Money Laundering Directive must also be fine-tuned to ensure effective identification opportunities. An overall challenge is the issue of financial inclusion. If you as a citizen do not get access to the most basic financial services, life will be very difficult. No matter what measures we take, the issue of financial inclusion must always be at the center. The new Payment Directive will give every citizen the right to a basic bank account. Even if the step is in the right direction, we must not be content. Building a well-functioning internal market for financial services is a comprehensive project. At the same time, it is worth the effort if it creates real added value for Europe's citizens.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Olle Ludvigsson for his excellent report on retail financial services. Last year the Commission published its Green Paper on that subject. Its title was ‘Better products, more choice, and greater opportunities for consumers and businesses’. Those remain our objectives. We launched a consultation to ask consumers and businesses for their thoughts on how to achieve them. The responses are shaping our approach to deepening the single market for these services so as to enable consumers to make informed purchases that meet their needs wherever they might be in Europe and to allow financial firms to make the most of economies of scale, lower costs and improve service. We received more than 400 responses to our consultation. This underscores the need to tackle some of the barriers to cross-border retail financial services at European level. I am pleased to see that the conclusions of your report go in the same direction. Consumers cannot understand why, in our single market, it is still so difficult to purchase financial products from another Member State, particularly as other services are more easily available. Financial firms can have their ambitions to sell into bigger markets frustrated by additional requirements in different European countries. The Green Paper consultation has now closed. The Commission issued a feedback statement in July and we will follow up with an action plan on retail financial services next year. It will cover a number of areas touched upon in Mr Ludvigsson’s report. The action plan will tackle barriers that consumers face when they want to access financial products at a distance. We want to make it easier for consumers to be identified remotely without weakening important anti-money laundering requirements. We will look into reducing obstacles which financial firms can face when they want to expand into another European country without establishing a physical presence. And we want to give consumers the confidence that they need to purchase products across borders by giving them better access to reliable information and by making sure that they have a right to redress if things go wrong. The work that we are taking forward with a Consumer Financial Services Green Paper is part of our broader push to build a single market for capital in Europe, a capital markets union. Working together we have a real opportunity to strengthen the single market around the principles of transparency, competition and choice, and we can make the daily lives of European consumers easier. This is an opportunity and, by working together, I hope we can take it.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Mr President, Commissioner, when we analyze the market for retail financial services, that is, the products where citizens save their savings, health insurance, pension plans, car insurance, even financing mechanisms For companies and families, we find markets, firstly fragmented, that also promote increased costs because they avoid competition between different operators; We find rigid markets, which make it impossible to carry some products from one Member State to another; and we also find ourselves with opaque markets, which make it impossible to compare the same products, similar products, as I say, between different operators in different Member States. And therefore the Green Paper that you have presented is an opportunity to do three things at the same time: one, to regulate and end the fragmentation that today dominates the markets at European level; two, to empower and protect consumers as well; and three, to seize, for growth, the opportunities of digitization. End fragmentation: but there, Commissioner, we do not believe in good practice or good intentions. We need regulation, that the existing one is fulfilled and that the gaps that it has left are covered. We do not believe, as I say, that it is not necessary to move from the Green Paper to concrete legislative actions that guarantee equal opportunities and also avoid fragmentation between Member States. Empower consumers, through increased transparency, increasing their confidence, the comparability of products, and, for that, we propose a tool that allows comparability between the same products from different Member States, and, fundamentally, agile, fast, safe mechanisms for conflict resolution between different Member States.And third, all of this can be done by promoting, taking advantage of, the opportunities of digitization.But let me just focus on one issue: fintechs.It is also a new opportunity to improve financing at European level, far beyond the abusive bank dependency that we have in the Community area.But for this it is also necessary to better regulate how these operate in monetary loans.We have to establish the same rules, the same protections and requirements that the traditional banking system has for those new operators who take advantage of the new digitalization technologies to open new business fields.New rules and networks, the same opportunities, also with the same safeguards as those we already know in the traditional market.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Ludvigsson for this report. It is a very important discussion and very important substance. I think we have every opportunity now to do what we can in order to achieve an efficient and liquid European financial market. Digitalisation means that we will have all these opportunities. It will open things up for the fintech industry and a lot of new services, but it will also create better competition, better credit situations, and better credit opportunities. The challenge for us is to set all these things in the perspective of digitalisation, because while it makes most things possible, we can still see that legislation and regulations are hindrances. I think it is important to see what we can do in order to do what we must do.  First of all, we can create better credit situations all over Europe: liquid markets. Second, we can secure for consumers their being able to use a new range of services in other countries, but also being able to use services from other countries in their own country. You can move from country to country, having your pension with you, but also having the opportunity to pay your invoices which is, by the way, quite important. And you will be able to participate in all the new services, in parallel with banks, competing with banks, but also in innovating financial markets. It will create new jobs, but it will also give a more efficient European economy.  I think, in order to achieve this, that we need to secure an open mind for all the new competition that will arise. That has to do with how we deal with the Payment Service Directive. I think banks will still be as important as they are, but if we can open up new arenas and new opportunities for credit and for financing and new services, we must do that in order to help consumers. I think we need to implement a number of items of legislation that so far are not as implemented as they should be – the Mortgage Credit Directive, taking one example – but also set all the other legislation we have in place.  Digitalisation is not new. It has dominated the financial sector for quite a long time. But the thing that we need to do is to ensure that we facilitate all the opportunities that digitalisation can provide for European financial markets. That is why this discussion is very important. Once again, my congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for your initiative with this Green Paper on financial services. I believe that my colleague Ludvigsson's report provides a good analysis of your proposals. Basically, the central question now is how to mobilize individual savings and put them at the service of a European strategy which is necessarily a long-term investment strategy. For this, I believe that the proposal we are making for a European savings product must be seriously examined by your Commission. I know that low rates do not create an environment favorable to such a proposal, but you would thus respond, in my opinion, to an aspiration of our fellow citizens and offer a means of finding funding for an investment in favor of the ecological transition. Such progress must also go through the issue of consumer protection, which can never be ignored. From this point of view, I hope that we will be able to quickly lead to this famous PRIIPs legislation on which we are trying to lead. However, we can see it clearly, and this is very significant, the operators of different sectors want to be able to compete with each other to collect savings, but then they do not want us to be able to compare their products in an open and transparent manner. The legislator and the Commission must be very firm in this area. My colleague spoke a lot about FinTech. I am also in favor of FinTech, but I think that, in this area, the supervisors and the European Commission must be very vigilant, because I observe here and there the development of trading platforms which are sometimes pure scams against which the Europe must act by mobilizing more strongly ESMA and the competent national authorities. Finally, we expect from you, when you will examine the next proposals on the capital markets union, that you do not forget the commitments to which you invite us through this Green Paper.At that time, we will be by your side to progress.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Retail financial services are an important part of the daily life of citizens. We are discussing here a good report that broadly presents solutions related to financial services, at the same time pointing to the development potential of this sector and emphasizing the creation of a more open, non-discriminatory and competitive market. Consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises will undoubtedly benefit from such improvements. Personally, I only disagree with paragraph 29, which refers to the adoption of the single currency by all Member States without exception. Ladies and gentlemen! We know perfectly well that no regulations are indifferent to all affected parties. Therefore, I appeal to the European Commission to carry out an appropriate assessment of the effects on the business environment before proposing further regulations in this area and others, so that they do not constitute a burden for entities providing financial services and entities using them.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur for doing a very good job and ensuring a compromise that will indeed be supported by my Group. As the previous speaker said, this is a very important topic for citizens. This is about everyday products that they use. Everybody has insurances, loans, mortgages, pension savings, investment accounts, etc., but we see that only three percent of the market – three percent of the potential – is being used and that is worrying. But I have to say that what worries me even more is the lack of ambition and the lack of urgency – just look around the room – because, even if the report is very good, we shy away from the taboos. I also note that the Commission had initially planned to come forward with an action plan in September and now the talk is about next year. I understand that some people are afraid of rapid developments – fintech was mentioned – but this is reality. This is what is happening and, as long as we sit on our hands, we will be overtaken by other parts of the world. If I look at the level of investment by the United States and China, this overtakes the European Union by far. The European Union is fragmented into 28 national markets. We are weak and not attractive for investors.  I get very worried when I read in the newspaper that a major European bank is actually investing EUR 20 million euros in fintech in China. It should be the other way around. We should be attractive enough for Chinese investors to come here and develop our own services. Europe has the potential to become the hub for retail financial services but, if we do not act more speedily, with more urgency and with more ambition, then we are going to lose the race because, colleagues – or those of you who are still around – this is not necessary for multinationals; they will find their way anyway. This is, however, urgently needed for consumers and SMEs, because they do need the European Union in order to eliminate the barriers. ALDE and the Green Group have tabled amendments and I very much hope for the support of the EPP Group and the S&D Group, because we do not think it is enough to make noble statements here about the objective of eliminating barriers, maybe sometime next century. We need concrete deadlines and we need concrete objectives. That is why we hope that these amendments mentioning the deadlines will be adopted. Finally, it is a pity that, as usual, the Council is absent – the Council representing the Member States – because we all know that the biggest obstacle of all is national governments protecting their national champions. So where are they? Even the biggest Eurosceptics are always saying how important the internal market is. The government leaders are always saying how important the internal market is but, when it really comes down to it, they are actually blocking the opening—up of the internal market, doing a big disservice to their own citizens. So I hope that the Commission will come up with a really ambitious action plan as soon as possible.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I believe that the Commission would be wrong if it does not greatly strengthen financial protection. Fundamental services, such as having a bank account or accessing cash, cannot be subject to huge fees. Products as simple as deposits or mortgages should not be open to fraudulent practices as serious as those of the preferred or the benchmark of mortgage loans. The offer of existing financial products must be simplified and basic banking services offered as a right - for example, through a public bank. And, in this sense, linking the reform of financial services to the banking and capital union, that is, to the liberalization, privatization and concentration of the financial sector, is a serious mistake. We must not forget the workers in the sector either: developments such as digitization, in addition to opening a gap with many consumers, are so far synonymous with job insecurity, which also requires new regulation at European level.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, enhanced international competition in consumer markets certainly has the potential to give customers a better deal for insurance, banking, savings, investments and much else besides. In some product markets, benefits from competition are fairly straightforward to attain, but in retail financial services there are clearly complexities to be overcome in order to boost international competition. Many products rely on putative income streams or pay—outs far into the future, while charging regimes can be opaque, and let us not forget we are dealing with high value items designed to make a big difference to a person’s standard of life. This is not a pair of socks or a new pencil sharpener. The potential complexity of pursuing cross—border redress is one factor that has led thus far to pragmatic consumers tending to stick with suppliers from their own country of origin or residence. But, given the potentially large gains to consumers of being able to access the best advice and widest choice of products from across the world, Europe’s countries would do well to keep working at bringing down barriers in this field. As a world leader in retail financial services, the United Kingdom has much to offer the savers, investors and future pensioners of Europe. Any bid by the EU to use Brexit as a pretext for closing down consumer choice would leave Europe’s citizens facing a less prosperous and less secure future. Governments would be failing in their duty were they to allow this to happen.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – Mr President, firstly congratulations to Mr Ludvigsson and all the shadows for the work on this own-initiative report. I agree fully with those of you who spoke about the 28 different legal regimes on our single market that fragment this market and do not allow it to use the whole potential that lies there. My committee, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), also contributed to this work; we provided an opinion. We all see that the retail financial market is, despite the number of legislative measures at the EU level, still not used. We will continue our work on it. Also in the report on the regulation on geoblocking, which you mentioned already, consumers encounter numerous barriers. Having a bank account or a credit card is a prerequisite to almost every economic activity. But if consumers have problems with those services, they cannot as a result access any other services or goods normally accessible on this market, not to mention consumers’ problems and consequent frustration with other services such as loans, mortgages, investment products, insurance, etc. According to the most recent Consumer Markets Scoreboard, those markets are quite poorly rated by consumers domestically, and the cross-border perspective is even worse by a long way. The single market and the digital single market cannot work effectively without cross-border retail financial services. This is one of the most important issues. Therefore, I would like to repeat the conclusions from our committee and ask the Commission to undertake a detailed examination analysis of both national and cross-border obstacles, remaining barriers to cross-border operations and to the completion of the single market financial sector. The European Commission needs to identify the reasons behind the existing market segmentation and price discrimination and the European Commission should recommend measures to encourage financial institutions to compete beyond national borders.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Mr President, the ability for everyone to access high-quality, safe and affordable financial services has become increasingly important. Olle Ludvigsson’s report offers many suggestions on how we can encourage new growth areas, including cross-border services. But, of course, we also need to consider how we can better protect consumers.  People can be financially excluded in many different ways; they may lack safe ways to borrow, encouraging them to turn to payday lenders or loan sharks, or they may be unable to access funds and services across countries – with one of my constituents finding it next to impossible to access funds stolen from her family by the National Socialists mainly because of administrative impediments.  So I am really pleased the rapporteur has taken on board many of my concerns, from calling for a simple, safe and portable financial products framework to acknowledging issues arising from the digital divide, to making sure incentive structures for staff in financial services do not promote mis-selling or inappropriate cross-selling, to advocating rigorous and consistent enforcement of consumer protection across states. British consumers have been subject to many of the same sharp practices and scandals as other Europeans. So I hope the UK Government will follow and emulate developments at EU level to improve retail financial services, rather than trail behind them.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: - We no longer live in an era of change, we live in a change of era. This is especially true when you look at the financial sector, because all new technologies, from the analysis of big data to robo advice, to blockchain, you name it: everything that comes together in new things at the same time nowadays changes the landscape enormously. This makes it possible for a great many products to become cheaper, better, faster and, I say to colleague Anneliese, also more accessible to a great many people. So there are a lot of opportunities, because the most important goal that we have all set here is to create jobs and economic growth. In order to achieve this, we must be able to compete internationally. In any case, we also need an advanced financial infrastructure for this. To this end, this report, and I congratulate Mr Ludvigsson on this, can provide an important impetus to ensure that we are innovation-friendly while ensuring consumer protection and, of course, also be aware of the systemic risks inherent in our entire financial system. We have to find that balance together, because as my colleague in 't Veld just said, an awful lot is invested in this all over the world. If we are not careful, we are lagging behind in this area. We harm our economy, but especially our citizens, because they really want to be able to participate at a global level. You just really need those innovations for that.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, we are facing yet another deepening of the single market, extending it to retail financial services. Like other initiatives, it is based on concepts that, apparently being aimed at improving users' conditions, represent, in practice, another element of harmonization, of deepening federalism, which will serve major financial interests, facilitating the concentration of wealth and the centralization of economic power. Some of the most perverse aspects of this initiative: liquidation of smaller companies and promotion of pan-European banking oligopoly; increase in the profits of large banks, namely by reducing operating costs, which include the dismissal of workers, processes facilitated by the digital aspect and the reduction of the physical implantation of companies; degradation of conditions for direct service to the public and job insecurity; deregulation of the economy and intensification of the free movement of capital; further suppression of the autonomy and sovereignty of the Member States; and facilitating capital flight, making it more difficult to combat money laundering. These are objectives and consequences that deserve our total rejection and condemnation.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as you have noted, the excellent report by my colleague Ludvigsson basically demands two things from the Commission. The first is to implement the legislation already adopted, because in applying the signed agreements there is a sense of credibility of the institutions that seems important to us. And then he asks the Commission for further initiatives, including the proposal for a savings account in the European Union and the encouragement of sustainable investments and, in particular, green ones. Why do these two requests go in parallel? Because there is a need to create awareness and strength in the internal market among users, consumers, who are the main subject to which to allocate the actions we ask of you. I would like to quickly return to two of the consumer aspects that you yourself mentioned. The first concerns information: correct information gives awareness to those who must use a service. In this way, he can choose what to do and with whom to do the actions he needs for the investment and for the enhancement of his savings. The second theme is that of appeals: the possibility of appealing gives security to those who invest. Unfortunately, today we suffer from a lack of awareness and also from a very high state of insecurity. If you make these choices, you will help strengthen the internal market and, above all, the subjects that operate within it, which are consumers.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: - Mr President! I would of course like to begin by thanking Olle Ludvigsson for his work. It is a fairly good base for further studies in the field. Most of us probably agree that the banks carry out important and versatile work that serves us all as private individuals, as small entrepreneurs, possibly also those who are large entrepreneurs. However, it raises some thoughts when you look at the information we see about the banks' return requirements. A bank that has a required return on its capital of 15 percent may be violating the rules that we in our great wisdom are writing here. This begs us a serious question as to how we can ensure that the rules actually create a game plan that is reasonably even and that enables small banks in smaller countries to survive in fierce competition. So we need a fair system. We need an even playing field. I hope that in its future work, the Commission will be able to take this into account and ensure that the peripheral banks and the peripheral banking system also succeed in a game that is sometimes hard and not always very clean.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Mr President, my Group supports Parliament’s response to the Commission Green Paper on retail financial services. The report rightly points out that a single approach to retail services across the EU would be counter-productive at the moment, given the diversity of actors and the different products on the market, which are often tailored to local markets. However, there are definitely improvements that can be made to the status quo, which the report highlights. For example, I am pleased that our amendments calling for the sector to work better for consumers, start—ups, investors and SMEs through delivering a healthy and competitive environment were adopted. I also support the emphasis placed on the simplification of legislation, the opportunities for digitalisation and fintech, the benefits of switching, and the financial education of consumers. We do, though, have concerns. For example, the creation of a common tax identification number is not something I support, as it goes beyond the competences of the EU. For this reason my Group will vote against this provision. I am also baffled as to why there are calls in this report for more Member States to adopt the euro. That has nothing to do with this report. I will also not be supporting amendments from colleagues calling on the European supervisory authorities to increase their activities on consumers’ and retail investors’ issues. We need to be careful about duplication of existing structures in Member States and ensure that taxpayers’ money is well spent.  The call to intensify work against geoblocking in the financial sector should not be legislative at this stage. My Group agrees with the Commission approach of a financial services carve-out, due to its complexity. On the whole, this is a good report with some positive recommendations for the retail financial services sector and we thank Mr Ludvigsson for his good work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, according to the Commission Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, all consumers should have access to transparent and honest products, and at the same time the main goal should be to combat tax evasion. The Green Paper promotes the reduction of market fragmentation, the digitization and the strengthening of the consumer position, in order to improve the functioning of the single market. Of course, consumer confidence in financial services is quite low, mainly due to the lack of financial knowledge on the part of consumers themselves. Also, many times the increase in the number of cross-border transactions creates problems, as it requires information about personal data. For this reason, it is necessary to extract personal data and this should always be done in accordance with the rules of data protection, while consumers should have the appropriate information about financial services.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in previous speeches, too, I have reiterated the need to implement transparency in transactions in the financial markets, with a view to building greater confidence in consumers. If retail financial services are only embryonic, it depends on the lack of transparency, coherence and protection of savings at the macroeconomic level and, above all, on the lack of respect for the principles of cooperation and exchange of information. A fundamental driver is the coordination with the digital single market but the responsibility in terms of privacy is great, if only one considers the phenomenon that quickly moves the first steps of "robo-advisory", which represents the most modern outpost of fintech. . But I wonder: how can we allow an electronic and no longer human operator to advise us on the purchase of financial products if we have not yet solved the crucial challenges of security, data protection, consumer protection, fair competition and financial stability at the level of Member States and central banks?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I also want to agree with my predecessors that it is the fragmentation of the legal framework of the 28 Member States that really discourages people from using these services.Due to their general complexity, people really need more information to have confidence in using retail financial services.At the level of the European institutions, it is precisely the information component of monitoring world developments and resolving some burning issues, which consist, for example, in determining the jurisdiction of the court that should decide any disputes arising from these legal relations, should be strengthened.There are a number of open moments.I want to support the Commission in the approach it has presented.I find it reasonable.We should now monitor global developments and propose an appropriate legal framework for the use of these services.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr Chairman, the rapporteur has made an accurate diagnosis that can be applied to other areas, not just retail financial services.It is necessary to use the full potential of available information technologies, but we must be aware that they can only remove administrative barriers.Other barriers, such as those of a legal and tax nature, can only be reduced by strong political will, which is all too often lacking.Although the regulations in this area are numerous, from the Payment Services Directive to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, the road to a truly single market will be neither quick nor easy.The rapporteur recognizes well that it is crucial to raise the level of consumer confidence and satisfaction.They still face relatively high fees in cross-border cash flows that do not match the real costs of service providers and this is an injustice that we need to correct.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for this engaging and interesting debate on the report. The Commission will take account of the issues which were raised today, and those outlined in the report, when preparing the retail financial services action plan. I believe our positions are similar in many ways. The Commission is focused on practical solutions. To keep the momentum, we will commit to actions which can be implemented quickly and which will bring tangible benefits to the everyday lives of consumers. So I agree that we need to be ambitious in this area.  In preparing our action plan, we will, of course, remain open to ideas and cooperation with stakeholders across the board, very much including the European Parliament. So I am looking forward to working closely and constructively with all of you to push this agenda forward.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! I have to thank you so much for the different opinions and views that have come to this with "retail financial services", for which I am very grateful. As rapporteur, I myself have tried to create as much unity as possible in Parliament, because I think that is important. The question we have before us about financial services is obviously important. It must be concentrated on consumers, the citizens, so that they can have safe and secure systems to operate in. I also believe that we should, of course, try to move forward as soon as possible. We can state that this is a complicated part that will take some time, but we must start in a sensible and reasonable way. What we did in our report was to divide it up in the short and long term, which I think is very, very important to do. We must also look up and look at the younger generation. It is the younger generation who will live with this. We must create the conditions for these products to be cheaper, better, more efficient and safer. That is the most important thing. In addition, we must of course try to speed up if possible. A big thank you once again to all the shadow rapporteurs, a big thank you to all the parliamentarians who have now taken part in the debate. I still feel that there is a fairly large consensus on where we want to go and what we want to do, and I hope for continued good cooperation on this issue. I also thank the Commission for the proposal that has been put forward.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the completion of Basel III, by Roberto Gualtieri, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (O-000136/2016 - B8-1810 / 2016) (2016/2959 (RSP))

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: author. – Mr President, this debate takes place one week before the next meeting of the Basel Committee in Chile, which will be an important step in the process towards the finalisation of the so-called Basel III agreements with a fundamental review of the banking book. As we know, this review is focused on three groups of measures: the review of the standardised approach for credit and operational risk, in order to enhance the risk sensitivity and robustness; the introduction of constraints to the use of internal models; the potential introduction of capital ouput floor based on the standardised approaches that defines the minimum amount of capital requirement for internally model exposures. The Parliament will be called, as co-legislator, to introduce the outcomes of this review into EU law. Taking into account the relevance and potential impact of the measures under discussion, we consider it necessary to intervene in the debate. We had an exchange of views with the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the Commission, the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the Secretary-General of the Basel Committee, and we drafted this oral question and the resolution, which has been approved by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) with a very broad majority and will now be put to the vote before the plenary. As the resolution clearly states, we believe in the importance of sound global standards, and we reaffirm that banks need to be well capitalised in order to support the real economy and reduce risk. We also consider it important to increase simplicity, comparability and convergence of the risk-weighted capital framework in order to address excessive variability in risk-weighted assets and to apply the same rules to the same risks. However, we think that the current revision, in order to be effective and not to have unintended and counterproductive consequences, needs to fully respect two principles. Firstly, it should not significantly increase overall capital requirements for European banks as the Basel Oversight Board has clearly stated. Secondly, the revision should not have a negative impact on the level playing field at global level. It should not exacerbate – rather it should mitigate – the differences between types of banks and between geographical areas, and it should not unduly penalise the EU banking model. As we know, although the draft standard has been built up by specific proposal subject to public consultations and specific quantitative impact studies, during the summary many concerns have been expressed and it clearly emerged that the various drafts did not respect the two above-mentioned principles. For this reason, we are calling on the Basel Committee to revise its proposals. We also call on the ECB, the SSM and the Commission to ensure the respect of the two principles in the finalisation and monitoring of the new standard. As the resolution clearly states, we consider that this would be instrumental for ensuring a consistent incorporation of the new measures into EU legislation. We understand that some steps in the right direction have been taken, and we encourage all the remaining critical elements to be addressed. As regards the use of internal models, they need to address the variability of risk-weighted assets should not be a reason to drop the sensitiveness of prudential requirement. It should be rather an incentive to deal with lack of organisation in modelling approaches, as the EBA and the SSM have already been doing since 2014, in order to ensure that risk-weighted assets are always consistent with the actual risk behaviour of banking assets.  Last, but not least, the resolution expresses concerns about the potential effect on the real economy of the possible introduction of output floors. The output floor is closely linked to the leverage ratio, and the new standard should ensure that the level of calibration of these two measures does not lead to an unintended duplication that could not only end up with an undoubtedly punitive outcome for the euro in terms of capital requirements, but also undermine the effectiveness of the overall reform package. In conclusion, with this resolution the Parliament reaffirms its commitment to work on agreed international standards, but at the same time it warns that those standards should fully take into account the specificity of the EU banking model and strike the right balance between stability and growth. We hope that the adoption of this resolution with a broad majority will contribute to this balanced outcome.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, as you know, the Basel Committee is currently reviewing the rules on capital requirements for banks. The declared aim is to find a better balance between risk sensitivity, simplicity and comparability of the outcomes of those rules. A key focus of the Basel Committee is the use of internal models. Specifically, the Basel Committee considers that, under the current rules, capital requirements calculated using source models can vary in a way that does not always reflect the differences in banks’ risk profiles, and feels that such unjustified variations should be tackled. The Commission supports the Basel Committee’s broad objectives, but we are also clear that we need an intelligent solution which maintains a risk—sensitive approach to setting capital requirements and which does not significantly increase capital requirements. We believe that the work undertaken by the Basel Committee would lead to less variability in risk-weighted assets, but not all variability is bad. In fact most of the variability is perfectly justified as it reflects actual differences in risk. It is important to ensure that the capital framework continues to reflect these differences. It is perfectly normal for a bank focused on lending in a sector and region with low risks to have lower average risk rates than a bank operating elsewhere.  A problem we see with the proposals made by the Basel Committee is that they could potentially come at the expensive of reducing some of the justified variability, which would result in less risk-sensitive rules. The revisions contemplated by the Basel Committee should recognise that in a number of areas banks and borrowers in Europe have their particularities.  As William Coen told the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) recently, the Basel Committee has already made important changes to the revisions of the rules proposed initially and on some, but not all, EU specificities had to be taken into account through those changes. For example, the capital requirements for mortgages have been adjusted to take into account the very stable mortgage markets we have in the EU.  However, the Commission considers that, at this stage, the changes do not fully ensure a level playing field between the different regions in the world. In terms of the impact of capital requirements and on financial stability, the Basel Committee’s proposals could address some weaknesses in the current rules and could therefore increase the soundness of the banking sector and, consequently, financial stability. At the same time, taken together, the proposals could lead to a potentially significant increase in the capital requirements of EU banks, which would have an adverse effect or impact on lending to the economy, at least in the short term. So we need to find a solution which would not unduly weigh on the financing of the broader economy in Europe. At a time when we are focused on supporting investment, we want worldwide changes which would lead to a significant increase in overall capital requirements shouldered by Europe’s banking sector.  This is not just the Commission’s position. All Member States backed it in July and I understand that the resolution to be voted on in plenary on Wednesday goes very much in the same direction. Indeed this approach has been agreed by the Basel Committee itself so that the completion of Basel III should not lead to overall significant increases in capital requirements.  The Commission remains committed to the work done in the Basel Committee and we believe that it is in everyone’s interests to find a balanced solution. The Commission will keep on working intensively to ensure a solution that works for Europe and that does not put our banks at a disadvantage compared to our global competitors.

name: Markus FERBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen! In July of this year, on my initiative, a question for an oral answer was put to the Commission here in the European Parliament in plenary. My colleague Katainen was here at the time and gave us clear confirmation that the special needs of European banks should also be taken into account in the Basel Committee. That is why we in the EPP Group supported the initiative from the outset to also form an opinion in the form of a resolution in plenary. I would like to express my thanks to our committee chairman, who took on the task of preparing the resolution, also for the constructive way in which we discussed this in committee. We have to be clear about one thing: banks must of course be able to bear their own risks. We have done a lot for that. This week we will also receive proposals from the Commission to revise the capital adequacy rules, and we will continue on this path. But we also have to be careful that we operate the whole thing with a sense of proportion. Proportionality is a theme that we have included in all of our legislation. When implementing Basel II, we have forced all banks in the European Union to apply a risk standard if they do not have an internal rating model. I have no understanding that this model is suddenly to be made available again in Basel and that small and medium-sized banks in particular have to meet special capital requirements that neither comply with the principle of proportionality nor with risk weighting. That is why I very much welcome, Mr Vice-President, that the Commission made it clear from the start that the SME correction factor or SME support factor should be maintained, even if that was criticized in Basel. That was also very important to us as the EPP: We have to pay attention to how we implement Basel. Basel does not apply to the European Union, but is a global appointment. If I look at other economic areas - Roberto Gualtieri pointed out in his speech: Not all economic regions of the world are implementing Basel as we have done so far. We should also consider here whether a one-to-one implementation for all banks or perhaps only a partial implementation would be correct. One last comment I would like to make: we Europeans should learn to work together in Basel too. We have a number of central banks and a number of supervisory authorities on the Basel Committee. If Europe worked better together in the interests of our banking sector, we could take the lead in the Basel Committee and not the Americans, and I think we Europeans have what it takes.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, we are discussing here what the Basel Committee is going to adopt by the end of the month and I think it is very important that, as Vice-President, you attend this discussion and you can be the advocate of this Parliament, since deep down, we know very well that we are the main users - the main beneficiaries, if I may say so - of the work of the Basel committee. We are the ones who apply these standards drawn up in Basel with the most seriousness and consistency. The voice of Europeans must be heard and what we represent as a banking model must be represented. From this point of view, the questioning of the internal model raises questions, because we know very well that many banks in Europe use this model effectively and that it makes it possible to refine the financing conditions of the economy. From the point of view of the financing of the real economy - a subject which must nevertheless concern us as a priority when we are interested in the health of the banking sector - the hearing of Mr. William Coen in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is not did not completely reassure us. I would not want us to engage in a review of bank capital that does not fully take into account the investment needs of our economies, whether in the housing sector, and therefore on the issue of mortgage loans - which is a topic on which the Basel committee is looking with perhaps very disruptive effects for this fragile market, at the heart of the recovery of economic activity in many of our countries -, or on the issue of infrastructure financing, at the heart of the Juncker Plan strategy, which we also support. Finally, I note that in the resolution that we are going to vote by a large majority - I hope - we again raise the issue of the distribution of dividends by banks which, moreover, appear to be under-capitalized, a question which must be of concern, Mr. Vice-President, when we are looking for ways to regain the confidence of citizens in their banking sector.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I am delighted to have you here this evening, because I believe that, even if the crowds are not present around you, it is still very important that you take the time, as has been said previously, to come and discuss with the representatives of the Europeans. In the spring, we adopted by a large majority an own-initiative report which insisted on the need for both transparency and accountability of bodies like the Basel Committee. Therefore, we very much appreciate that you are here. I also very much appreciate, personally and on behalf of the group, that you have taken very clear and very firm positions on a subject on which we have not always received such clear messages from the Commission. A first step was the arrival of Mr Coen in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I believe that we can also congratulate ourselves that he came, even if, of course, a single debate cannot be enough to establish relations of trust. This will have to be followed over time by a dialogue. Today I would like to send two messages. The first is pretty obvious, but I think it bears repeating over and over again: we are in favor of international cooperation. It is obvious that Europe wants to be open and work with others, but there is no question that this will ultimately translate into a greater impact in Europe than in other areas of the world on the financing of economy. Mario Draghi told us earlier, in your presence, that we are barely starting to regain pre-crisis growth levels after eight years. So there is really no need to undermine growth in any way, and it will have to be done. On this point, in fact, we are counting a lot on the Commission to work to reconcile the positions of the States. I hope there can be a follow-up to the own-initiative report I mentioned, so that both in the Council and the Commission, between the ECB and the European Banking Authority, we can better defend European interests together, without necessarily create very cumbersome procedures, always taking care not to jeopardize the financing of the economy. One last remark about the American elections. I remember that for this report I went to Congress last year. I had been very struck by the opposition between the Democrats, on one side, and the Republicans, on the other, around the Dodd-Frank Act and the Volcker rule. It's a little early to find out, but maybe the election of Donald Trump will have an impact on how Americans view regulation. I would like, Mr. Vice-President, that we try as much as possible not to find ourselves in Europe to make progress at the Basel Committee with Americans from the previous administration and then be confronted with the day when we will have to work, with partners, including other regions of the world, who would no longer agree to move forward. Therefore, I ask you to be vigilant, as you have known to be so far.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, after the neoconservative wave of the 1980s and the neoliberal fury that deregulated the financial sector, it soon became apparent that private banking needed some rules under penalty of jeopardizing the entire system. The rules created from Basel 1 to 3 are intended to impose minimum levels of equity. However, the rules for their accounting have become increasingly complex and opaque, as is always the case with interest groups that always profit from the lack of transparency. Today, the citizen learns that the risk assessment models of the assets are the responsibility of the so-called systemic banks, unlike the others that are subject to a standardized model, that is, we have, as was demonstrated by a study by Standard & amp; Poor's, assets with different weightings from bank to bank, that is, we have a system in which the solvency ratios and stress tests are completely manipulated by the big banks, thus removing any credibility from the supervision system. For our part, the solution is very simple. Credit is too important to be left to the private sector's free enterprise. Public control over banking and the financial system is today more than evidence, it is a necessity.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Basel III completion package is far from perfect, but rejecting it in its entirety, in my opinion, is a completely wrong and dangerous approach, because it favors those who would like a return to financial deregulation in Europe. I believe that it is necessary to understand that today's crisis is, instead, the very daughter of a deregulation of the financial markets that began in the 1980s. The EU looks at the straw, in this case, and does not look at the beam. The problem of our banks is not "Basel yes or Basel no", but a system crisis that has been "euro-induced" and the introduction of new rules that have been asymmetrical and distorting and have damaged our banking system. I think three small steps are enough to heal our system. The first step must be to pull the plug on the single currency, which is causing an endless crisis within the eurozone system and therefore within the banks. Two: get rid of the banking union. And three: to adopt stringent regulation that starts with the separation between investment banks and commercial banks.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis! We are discussing the reform of Basel III a week before the crucial meeting of the Basel Banking Committee in Chile. At the same time, the new US administration wants to abolish the Dodd-Frank Act. During the election campaign, President-elect Trump declared that higher capital requirements and tighter supervision would restrict bank lending. And after his election victory, he has now announced that "the Dodd-Frank Act will be dismantled and replaced with new regulations that promote economic growth and job creation". Economic growth, job creation and investment - that is what we need in Europe now. And to do this, we need European banks that provide companies, private individuals and the public sector with sufficient liquidity, that is, provide the appropriate financing. With the draft of the equity and liquidity standards now available in the Basel Banking Committee, we will achieve exactly the opposite: European banks will lose competitiveness and profitability as a result of the new Basel III rules, as they will reduce their internal risk assessment by 25 to 30% - as far as the smaller ones are concerned - and some even need 50% more equity to back up their loans. This massive increase in the capital adequacy of banks, which is being sought by the US in particular, could lead to credit bottlenecks. Small and medium-sized enterprises, which have few other forms of financing, are particularly affected. For this reason, it is particularly important that the use of internal models for risk assessment, with which banks are allowed to calculate their own risks and thus their capital requirements, is maintained, no matter how much the US negotiators push for an output floor to be introduced.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! First of all, thank you to Commissioner Dombrovskis for representing European interests in relation to the Basel Committee. The Basel Committee is not a democratic institution and many EU countries are not represented. The Basel Committee is past, not present at all and totally undemocratic! We will have to raise this debate as well. I think that is worrying, and it means that the committee's findings do not always hit the spot on a broad comb and may risk hitting some countries much harder than others completely unjustifiably. Of course, it is important that we have a level playing field globally and that we ensure that the banks are properly prepared for future crises, but we must therefore be careful in Europe that we do not just dance to the American pipe when the Basel Committee's work implemented in the EU. We have to take into account the different European banking markets, and we cannot work with a model based on "one size fits all". If we are to uncritically accept a different risk assessment method than the one we have today, then we are doing ourselves a disservice! In the end, we run the risk of making much less of a distinction between secured and less secure loans. It will make it more expensive to borrow, whether the loan is for a secure or less secure purpose. We must remember that we in Europe are particularly based on the fact that our SMEs are financed through the banks, and we must not make it so expensive to borrow money that we are slowing down growth in Europe. So at the moment we have a Juncker plan, where we go out and finance a lot of small and medium-sized enterprises, and then there are people in the Basel Committee who want to do the opposite, namely pull growth out of our SMEs, reduce the opportunities for that SMEs can borrow money in the future because the financial institutions are going to pad themselves. It is simply not connected, and I have high hopes that Commissioner Dombrovskis will be able to defend our interests in this matter.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: - During the time of the financial crisis, we saw many banks worldwide get into trouble and we had to save banks with tax money. We had to do that in my country too. Of course we never want that situation back. That is why it is very good that the capital requirements for those banks have been increased, because banks must simply be able to keep up their own pants. What we now see at the Basel Committee, however, is that standards are being set at an international level, whereby everyone is treated in the same way while the situation is not the same. Because, as has already been said by other speakers, our banking system is really different from, for example, the American one. If you look at the situation surrounding mortgages, for example, we in the Netherlands actually suffered hardly any loss on mortgages, even at the depths of the crisis in the housing market. It is therefore not logical that you treat them in the same way as the mortgages in America, which have caused many problems there. I am therefore very pleased that we as a Parliament can jointly send a strong signal that we do not want it as the Basel Committee is now proposing, because our entrepreneurs have had very difficult access to credit in recent years. If we were to apply these requirements again, they would come from rain to drip. As far as we are concerned, Vice-Commissioner Dombrovskis can, to use football terms, with a straight leg, in the Basel Committee, represent our interests and properly represent our interests.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, I would simply like to recall the order of speeches, because I have a colleague who has been called and who should not have been.So I wouldn't want to waste the minute of speaking time that I'm going to need for my group.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to underline one thing that is important for the whole of this discussion: if you want to have a stable financial sector then you need to have a stable economy with growth and investments. You cannot look upon the financial sector as isolated from the economy as such. What we can see today is that an important part of the financial instability in the European Union is the lack of loans and investments, because that creates a vicious circle – decreasing investment, decreasing innovations, decreasing and undermined competitiveness, lower profits and increasingly non-performing loans and instability. Those things are linked together, and that is why we need to look upon the requirements for stability from the whole economy as such, and not only from one part of the economy. The financial economy is not decoupled from the rest of the economy, and in Europe banks are dominating regarding financing of SMEs but also financing on households and housing. They do a lot of different business, and that is why it is wrong to have the same sort of leverage rate for all sorts of banks. In the US, you have the banks that are one part of the financial sector, one part of the capital markets and may be focusing more on high—level business risks, while in Europe you have the whole perspective. That is why it is important to go further on regarding stability – to have the risk based approach but also to ensure that banks can lend money in order to secure that we can have growth in the economy. That is why, when we discuss Total Loss-absorbing Capacity (TLAC) we need to include it in the banking recovery resolution directive and the discussion about the MREL, and not to invent higher capital requirements but to secure that we have more stable banks and more stable growth in the economy.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Roberto Gualtieri, for his work on this report to define how to apply Basel, in a few days, in a few weeks before a very important meeting. The truth is that many times we discuss the structural reforms that we have pending in the European economy and very rarely do we speak of the need for this structural reform to affect the banking system. Because banking continues to be a serious problem for the economic recovery of the euro zone, of the whole of Europe; it is still a problem for monetary policy to work; It is still a problem for cheap credits to reach citizens and small businesses, and it is important that in this framework we discuss how to apply the new Basel measures and how to take them into consideration and apply them, as I said, to European regulation. Because it is true that in the years prior to the crisis, the whole world and Europe advanced in a system of financial liberalization that all it did was increase the growth of debt and lead us to the crisis of 2007-2010 in recent years . Therefore, we now have to be prudent in applying these measures because we have at stake the economic recovery, the health and safety of the banks and the future of employment in Europe.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: - Mr President! A discussion on the Basel rules would in fact presuppose a slightly greater participation here in Parliament and a greater enthusiasm for the task. If we look at the history of the Basel agreements, we can say that they have reflected the illusions that politicians at various stages have had about banking operations. During the crisis of 2007–2008, we had a bitter experience, ie. a large part of that crisis actually arose on the basis of the incorrect rules written by the Basel Committee. For that reason, it is of the utmost importance that we succeed in rewriting these rules and actually implementing them in a way that makes them work. In this regard, we are a little concerned about the current situation in the Basel Committee, ie. that European banks are not able to defend their interests but rather fly around like a flock of sparrows. This is a worrying sign, and we therefore hope that the Commission will take this seriously and ensure that we have a united banking front that is able to safeguard the interests of European banks.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, I would like to refer to three issues which I consider crucial when it comes to Basel III. The first one is the comparability of internal models, and this is a precondition for proper supervision. Models must be comparable across the institutions supervised. So we must keep up the good work which is already done in this area – and it is not only about the work of the European Banking Authority (EBA) but also about the functioning of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), which takes us towards a common understanding of the assessment and the approval of models. I believe that the use of internal models, in which there has been huge investment in recent years, enables information to be processed better and with a higher level of granularity than a standardised approach would permit. Given that these have been introduced only relatively recently, it is no surprise that we still need to figure out how to fine tune some concepts and rules. And, in this context, transparency on the process of granting authorisation to use internal models seems a key point. The second issue is that of proportionality. I would be in favour of a wide definition of the term as a fair balance between the costs and benefits of a measure for each group of stakeholders, so that the new rules do not result in a disproportionate burden on some types of banks or some regions of the world.
