The last issue is that of global standards. My belief is that, if we want to avoid global fragmentation, we should adhere to these closely, in particular when we regulate an activity such as finance, which is transnational and cross-border in nature. I can understand that some would want to depart from the global standards on certain points, when they are not suited to specific situations. But the best way is to act before tensions arise, and to try to influence the standard-making process at global level, and we are well represented in Basel, so we are equipped to do that if we speak with one voice.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, the new banking supervision rules under development in Basel 3, in particular on the methodology for assessing credit risk, raise two particularly important issues.The first is whether or not these new regulatory requirements are at risk of further limiting the flow of credit available to households and businesses and what safeguards the Commission will adopt to protect an economy that needs credit to grow.The second issue is that of proportionality, so knowing how these rules will adapt to the different size, risk level and business model of the various financial institutions.What guarantees can the Commission give us that what is equal will be treated as equal and what is different will be treated as proportionally different.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - The agricultural sector and small and medium-sized enterprises are very concerned about the future lending of the Basel IV standards. Of course, financial stability and a robust banking sector with sufficient equity capital are paramount, but there are fears that the proposed rules will have serious consequences for this real economy. The agricultural sector in Europe and the Netherlands is currently in a difficult period, partly due to low milk prices and the Russian boycott. The agricultural sector, especially young farmers with a lot of equity capital in the form of land, often has to take out a new mortgage, among other things in order to comply with animal welfare, the nitrates directive and the climate agreement. Therefore they need a continuation of their mortgage. The future of many farmers depends on the provision of transitional credits. The same also applies to our construction sector, which is emerging from a deep trough. Citizens must be able to continue to obtain a mortgage to buy a house. That is why the European Commission must not remain on the sidelines. There is a possibility to use key instruments, such as the Juncker Plan, and this proposal is also made in the report by Cees Veerman of the Task Force on the future of the agricultural sector. Finally, what you must remember from my speech is that we must prevent a credit crunch. Economic growth, the stimulation of the job market and the continued existence of a powerful agricultural sector in Europe demand this. Europe stands for peace, but also for sufficient food, sufficient credit to continue to produce food, including through family and family businesses. What is a liveable countryside without a healthy farming population, and of course a healthy bank.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the big challenge is how to kick-start economic growth and create new jobs. Banks are key players in achieving this goal by bolstering the EU economy. However, we have to ensure that banks are stable and well capitalised because they are fundamental to sustainable economic growth. As co-legislator, Parliament needs to assess carefully the qualitative and the quantitative impact of these new reforms on the European economy, in particular the financing of infrastructure and real assets. Therefore we need to be mindful that we are not disadvantaging the European competitive position. But to do this we need to recognise that we must speak with one voice. Global developments in recent weeks mean there is a potential impact due to the result of the American elections. It is now unclear whether the US will stick to its commitments, and it may well be that Basel III/IV gets kicked into the long grass. Vice-President Dombrovskis, in the committee a fortnight ago, you were clear in saying that anything that leads to significant increases in overall capital requirements on Europe’s banking sector would be unacceptable to the Commission. Are you concerned about recent developments across the Atlantic, and about the potential implications for the finalisation of Basel III?

name: Paul TANG
text: - Anyone who reads the IMF's Global Financial Stability Report will be shocked. Europe has too many banks, too many weak banks and a few too large banks. There are also banks that are struggling with non-performing loans. There is no reason for European arrogance or complacency, quite the contrary. The resistance from the financial sector is not surprising and not very convincing. In their story, rules always stand in the way of growth. In their story, raising extra capital is always an obstacle. But let's face it, a well-regulated and well-capitalized financial sector is a prerequisite for economic growth. It is therefore good that this resolution, courtesy of the rapporteur, sends out a balanced signal that emphasizes the specific difficulties that may arise in the European market, but also shows the need for robust internal models and that banks should also must be sufficiently capitalized. Too often it has happened that banks have paid dividends but did not have their capital in order, with Deutsche Bank as a clear example. They have paid out another 5 billion in dividends since 2008. So I welcome this discussion, glad that Basel's important work is openly discussed in this room, but let's not be arrogant or complacent.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the financial crisis has shown us that there is an acute need to make our banks and finance institutions more robust to serve the real economy, investment and jobs – and not only in Europe but also globally. However, it is also very important that we have a risk-based approach to regulation, with the same rules being applied to the same risk, and the way we look at the Basel Committee and its recommendations is also very important in Europe. As you know, Commissioner, many countries are not members of the Basel Committee, and there are also ways of financing our economy that have proved to be very strong, even during the financial crisis. I would point to covered bonds – I come from Denmark and I see that some of the proposals put forward would hurt ordinary families with a mortgage loan which proved to be very robust during the financial crisis, or small and medium-sized enterprises that finance their businesses by mortgage loans, by covered bonds – and also to systems where we see consumer rights at the core. Such approaches give consumers transparency, supervision and affordability. It is essential that we keep that in Europe, so we need to regulate to make loans from risky banks more robust, but we also need to ensure that the system works well for the people, and that our economy is being protected so we can protect our competitiveness. I hope the Commission is well aware of that.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the Basle Committee must act as a matter of priority to address and resolve what seem to me to be the greatest difficulties affecting the banking sector today. As you know, banks are and will remain the main subject for investments also in the time to come, both those concerning businesses and those concerning households. The state of undercapitalization of some of them and the resulting risks, but also the unfair behavior towards investors, have created a negative climate that leads many people to be seriously worried and therefore to have a non-linear and non-transparent relationship with the banks. I believe it is very important to address this priority and at the same time give equally clear rules to the shadow banking system: any form of alteration in competition is an objective damage, on the one hand for the economy and on the other hand for investors.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Madam President! What the European Parliament is about to do here is extremely dangerous. We are running a high risk if we intervene here in the Basel process on the side of those who believe that we do not need to increase the capital requirements on banks any further. It is extremely dangerous if we continue to give the banks the freedom to use their internal models to carry out risk assessments and thus to reduce their capital requirements. We have been through a severe financial crisis, and this financial crisis came about because the banks had insufficient capital and the risk assessments were incorrect. And I am amazed when I hear this debate here now, where one speaker after the other is practically saying the same thing over and over again, namely that we are going to stall our economy and I don't know what anything. We then choke our economy when we produce a new financial crisis, when we risk a new financial crisis by already slacking off in the necessary regulation of the financial system. No, ladies and gentlemen, we need considerably higher capital requirements in the banks, considerably higher capital ratios. We have to get away from these internal models. We need to move to standard models so that the risk assessment is correct. That is the task of time!

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the prudential rules that the European Union imposed following the recommendations of the Basel Committee have helped to make the banks more responsible. It is very good. But constantly adding additional constraints would force European banks to lend less or more. Faced with American banks less framed by financial regulation, competition will become unequal. It will be all the more so since Donald Trump has clearly announced that he wants to reduce prudential regulations on American banks. What should the purpose of regulation be? It must both protect savers and ensure the stability of the system. But the banks continue to speculate. Shadow banking is taking flight, leverage and volatility are a concern again. To achieve these objectives of protection and financial stability, it is necessary to abolish the bail-in of the banking union and to ensure a true banking separation by cutting in two the risky market activities, deposit and credit activities. This is the complete opposite of what the European Union does. This is why the peoples need and want a recovery in hand of the financing of their economy by policies of economic patriotism.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: –Mrs President, Commissioner! I don't fully understand the excitement. On the one hand, we expect a proposal from the Commission to deepen Basel III. Here, the question of proportionality must be seen as a focus, both the definition and the effects of the definition on the real economy and, on the other hand, the extension of the SME factor, both in terms of the time frame and the amount. On the other hand, we have Basel, where we are waiting for Basel IV and there is still no agreement because there are rightly differences of opinion, especially between the European Union and the Americans. Here it is absolutely right for the European Parliament to raise its voice because Basel is not a legislator. The starting point is different. In America, the regulation affects 15 banks that operate internationally, and in our country it usually affects more than 8,000 banks. So we have to make sure that these differences are taken into account, that the different business models are taken into account and that there is an impact study before we decide anything.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic situation requires the re-establishment of adequate credit availability in the business system and greater monitoring of credit quality by banks. Basel III must first of all initiate a rethinking of the bank-firm relationship: the financial industry must in fact support the production system more in accessing the capital market and assisting in the identification of new forms of capitalization, while ensuring financial stability. In this context, the role of the Commission can and must be a driving force in ensuring a level playing field, in calibrating the final rules and in managing any increase in bank capital requirements. The transposition of the new regulations, in fact, if not carried out in a structured and coordinated way, could result in an average increase in the cost of loans to businesses, re-triggering the negative spiral of recent years.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, ensuring the stability and efficiency of the financial system is essential for economic and social prosperity. The revision of standard approaches to credit risk may lead to an increase in capital requirements, making it more difficult for banks to lend to businesses and households. It is estimated that the full implementation of the Basel III framework in 2019 is expected to bring European banks higher capital requirements in excess of € 550 billion. Given the already existing financial instability, the Commission should ensure that any possible increase in capital requirements will not have a negative impact on banks' lending capacity. Financial institutions must be able to provide liquidity for growth and job creation, especially to small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of the European economy.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Parliament for the useful elements and suggestions which have been provided during the debate. Banks’ capital requirements need to balance prudential aims with our jobs and growth agenda. Today’s debate has clearly shown the extent to which this matters to the EU institutions, and I am pleased to see that there is agreement on many key issues. We are committed to implementing these Basel standards in a way that makes sense for the EU. The Commission will continue to work on the issue with a view to growing solid and evidence-based policy recommendations and will carefully consider all the ideas which emerge from the discussions in our future work.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure, I have received a motion for a resolution1.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday November 23, 2016. (The sitting is suspended for a few moments) _______________ 1 See minutes

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is Urmas Paet's report on the European Defense Union (2016/2052 (INI)) (A8-0316 / 2016).

name: Urmas PAET
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the state of European security has grown increasingly fragile. The surge of instability and unpredictability around the Union borders is a reality and a cause of concern to all European citizens. In order to defend itself and increase its security, the European Union must do more and must be consistent. Our Union is not equipped to face overwhelming defence challenges. For almost 30 years, the majority of the Member States applied cuts in their defence budgets, leading to smaller armed forces. Cooperation among Member States is occasional, and Europe continues to rely heavily on NATO capabilities and on US solidarity. Many Member States have called, over the past year, for effective and increased cooperation on defence. Let us be clear: the momentum to move towards a working European defence policy is here. Tomorrow, Parliament is voting on the European Defence Union report. As rapporteur, my main recommendations included the goal for EU countries to spend 2% of their GDP on defence, helping to finance infrastructure in Member States at the Union’s eastern border, and establishing a military Schengen area. The role of NATO has been, is and will continue to be paramount. There is also no reason to say that EU defence cooperation is weakening NATO. This is simply not true. On the contrary, for years NATO has wished to see the EU as a partner complementing it. There are several issues on which the EU could improve its security cooperation internally as well as with NATO. At the moment, movement of the allies’ defence forces personnel is troublesome, bureaucratic and time consuming. The EU must create a system to change this reality: in other words, the so-called military Schengen should be established. We can talk endlessly about increasing the efficiency of defence costs – and that is necessary – but in order to reach a certain level of quality we need also quantity. The EU Member States must set themselves the goal of spending 2% of their GDP on defence, as the NATO countries have done. This would give a clear signal of the joint positions of the EU and NATO. In order to carry out the EU defence policy we must contribute additionally from our common EU budget. The right way to do this will be through the EU’s Multiannual Financial Framework. The EU can financially support, for example, the placement of international NATO battalions in the EU Member States by backing the building of necessary infrastructure such as roads, barracks and other facilities. At the moment, most of this burden falls on a few specific Member States who, due to their geopolitical location, need an increased NATO presence. At the same time, the increased presence serves as a protection for all the EU and NATO countries. The EU must also gear up the defence research programme and start developing a common European policy on capabilities and armament. We need to strengthen the industrial and technological base of our defence sector in order to decrease dependency on third parties. The practical steps also require a political framework in order to ensure sufficient political attention. Therefore, it would be reasonable to create the position of European Commissioner for Defence and to set up regular meetings of the EU defence ministers. Furthermore, it is necessary to establish the headquarters for the EU military operations. The Member States that are ready to undertake more binding commitments could set up permanent structured cooperation arrangements so that it would be possible to establish multinational forces. An option would be to further develop the EU battle group system. And, lastly, Europe can and must enable a real defence dimension without further delay. The Union must become proactive, especially in the security field.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Madam President! Many thanks in particular to our rapporteur Urmas Paet for his report. Indeed, we didn't need the wake-up call of the American presidential election to deal with the security and defense challenges. Ultimately, since the Lisbon Treaty came into force, a new possibility has been created to significantly strengthen cooperation. Permanent structured cooperation must now be tackled by the Member States, and we as Parliament have long supported this. In particular, I also support the ideas that the rapporteur has made, for example on the subject of battle groups, or - what I consider important - on the future financing of our activities. We need a fundamental reform of the Athens Mechanism. We cannot go on as before, so that the concept costs lie where they fall still applies. We also have to tackle this collectively.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, this report contributes to the search for more effective European Union responses in the field of defense. Our world is becoming increasingly unstable, insecure and unpredictable. We need to respond to growing challenges because not only our integrity but also our values ​​are at stake. To achieve this, Member States must work more closely together. Security and defense must not remain the weakest links in European integration. We need to listen to the citizens. Two-thirds of them want more cooperation. Failure to provide security to citizens will lead to further distancing from the European project and turning to national security solutions. The European Defense Union is not a parallel structure to NATO. It will be developed in full coordination with NATO as our primary partner and pillar of European defense. The report emphasizes this. I call on you to support him, because the European Parliament must be involved in a process that has progressed in the other institutions. The report would send a strong message on a topic that has become a first-class political issue and a criterion by which citizens assess the credibility of a European project.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, Europe is having a hard time responding to the security challenges posed by these turbulent times in which we live.The fact is that most member states spend too little on defense and that the times when Europe was safe, without too much spending on the military, are far behind us.But going back to solutions more than sixty years old will not bring us security.What was called the European Defense Community in the 1950s is now called the European Defense Union.It didn't come to life then, and it won't now.And there is no need for it to come to life.The foundation of the defense of Europe and our civilization in general is NATO.And we need to pay more attention to him.After the US presidential election, it became clear that there would be a redefinition of relations within NATO, and Europe must show a willingness to dialogue with America and other key partners and a determination to lead the defense of Western civilization and its values.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, in recent years the security situation in and around Europe has significantly worsened and has created challenges that no single country or organisation is able to face alone. These challenges therefore require the EU to act together with our allies. However, our current efforts to build the European Defence Union must also take into account the impact and constraints of the EU relationship with NATO. Twenty-two European Member States belong to both the EU and NATO and we do have common values, historically shared by both institutions. I firmly believe that an increase in European military capability, which I support, must be conducted in cooperation with NATO: not as a supplement to NATO but as a complement to it. Europe must focus energy and resources on fixing those tasks that NATO cannot do and is not equipped to do. That way, we will create both the security needed and the ability to deal with new tasks.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Madam President, this report delves into two errors: it focuses on the security dimension and the militaristic perspective, that is, it seeks solutions to security avoiding a holistic approach that combats economic, cultural and social asymmetries.Thus, there is no more security.In addition, it proposes the military deployment abroad, something dangerous considering the aggressive attitude that the European Union and some States maintain with our eastern and Mediterranean neighborhood.In addition, it calls for an increase in arms spending, something obscene when this European Union of inequality imposes draconian cuts in health, education and services.And, as a culmination, taking refuge in a supposed European defense Union, it proposes to reinforce the work of NATO: it is an obvious contradiction.We want a defense that seeks peace and not for the greater glory of aggressive designs or the profit and loss accounts of the arms companies.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Madam President!There is no doubt that the EU needs to do more for its own security.But about the report and the strategy that is being proposed, I have questions: How much more efficiency will it be if we increase defense spending to two percent?The EU currently spends three times as much on armaments as Russia, but we have significantly fewer capabilities.Is it about more money or is it about more efficiency?Second: Why does it contribute to security if we create zones of different security in the EU with a defense Schengen?Thirdly, why should the EU, by means of a presence - military presence - in the East, overturn certain restrictions that NATO has set for itself for good reasons?And fourthly: Why do we want more money for the budget without making it clear that the armaments budget must not eat into the EU's research investments?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, European defense has no meaning if it is not based on the independence of Europe and its own foreign policy. Independence means autonomy and sovereignty. For the moment, there was only one country which was in this policy in Europe, it was France, and Russia. Wanting to align European policy with that of NATO means wanting to share an aggressive and senseless policy that has led us to where we are. Moreover, this policy has changed. So we too would have to change. It is not serious not to want an independent and sovereign Europe and in this case, there is only one country which continues to want this independence and this sovereignty, it is my country. I would like to say that never, in the construction of Europe, have we managed to share such an objective. It is the failure of European defense for reasons of alignment with NATO policy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, defense and security are two important factors for a country's survival and prosperity. In this sense, the debate over the creation of a European Defense Union is reasonable. But the report is moving in the completely wrong direction. The need for collective defense of the European Union is being met by NATO. Most member states are also members of NATO and have forces in it. The European Union is not in danger of being attacked by a large and powerful military force, in order to overemphasize its defense capabilities. On the other hand, it does not mean that the European Union should become a gendarme in the region and invade, as the report states, with forces in neighboring countries. The security of each country is taken over by the national armies of the country, which are equipped and organized, while the countries have defense expenditures according to their obligations and needs. My country, Greece, is receiving threats from Turkey and I inform you that it has more than 2% of GDP for defense spending.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I have a different opinion than my predecessor and some of my colleagues.I believe that the EU must guarantee its citizens a sense of security, that we cannot resign ourselves to this fundamental value.I agree with the rapporteur and from my political group that securing defense policy is one of the fundamental tasks of the EU, which may not be clearly described in primary law, but we should strive for that.I see these forces and constituents as complementary to what NATO is doing, and it is our responsibility not only to involve the EP, as discussed here, in the formulation of this policy, but above all to hold EU Member States accountable, because they should ensureat least the financial framework that many countries have not met in the long run.Even my country does not spend two percent on defense, and I see it as our debt to common defense.The EU must not resign.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, as the alternate rapporteur for the S&D Group in the Committee on the Internal Market, I suggested to the Committee on the substance some things from the perspective of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. We have taken into account the situation of market fragmentation in the defense industry and, obviously, we have also thought about the problems that SMEs face in accessing contracts in this industry which, in fact, ensure a better defense. I asked the Commission to assess whether the objectives of Directive 2009/81 on the award of security and defense contracts had been achieved and to take the necessary measures to enable it to be adapted to the real needs of the defense market. I also suggested and encouraged the committee to strengthen research through funding in the defense sector. It is necessary because we are concerned about the declining budget for research and innovation in this area. And, of course, we are thinking about the skills gap that may arise due to the aging workforce and we encourage young people to go into this area to ensure a better defense of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the attempt to move forward by the European Union's dominant circles continues despite Brexit. The circumvention of the provisions of the Treaties with a view to launching a Euromilitary is now evident. The results of the US elections, which make NATO's future uncertain, and the concerns of some Member States about continuing their invasive plans in the Middle East and Africa, lead to decisions that have no democratic jurisdiction. The emerging Euro-army is not going to protect the Greek border from Turkish aggression and will follow in the footsteps of NATO, which represents Pontius Pilate in the Turkish threats against Greece. The field of defense is a field of competence of the national authorities. The Greek people will not accept the ultimatums and policies of the gunmen that Brussels and Berlin are trying to impose.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, this report does not bring us any news, it just confirms the militaristic and warlike nature of the European Union. The justifications are the same as always: insecurity on European soil or the alleged fight against terrorism, without any reference to the absolute failure of integration policies or to what were and are the European Union's responsibilities in aggressions against North African countries and Middle East, as well as in the promotion, financing, training and armament of extremist groups. Nor are the supposed threats from the east lacking to justify the siege of the Russian Federation. Subservience to NATO and its objectives, such as increasing the military budgets of the Member States to 2% of GDP and strengthening funding for military research and the military industry on European soil, does not hide the pretensions of having in the EU a large military bloc, with its own operational capabilities, namely through a European army. Whoever makes war and feeds his industry does not want or defend peace.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Madam President, the creation of a European Defense Union with a European headquarters, a European army, multinational NATO units, troop missions, based on the global strategy of the European Union, is a very dangerous development for the people. The military Schengen, as you call it, is a dangerous development, because it is a war preparation of the European Union while strengthening complementarity with NATO. This is how the aggression and the rivalries of the monopolies are expressed. In the criteria of the planned European Defense Semester and the White Paper on defense, the Greek government has already rushed to meet the above. Immersed in imperialist plans, it is already receiving praise from the United States, NATO and the European Union for its armaments, which exceed 2% of GDP, and has the Souda base as an upgraded base for new imperialist wars. The people must not shed their blood for the interests of the imperialists. They must intensify their struggle against the imperialist wars and the interventions of the European Union and NATO against their dirty plans.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Europe needs elementary solidarity today, not a European army, because that's what it's all about. President Juncker said a few days ago that the point is simply to create a European army. After all, in order for each of our countries to spend two percent of the national income on its own defense, we do not have to create a common army. After all, in order to stop the construction of Nord Stream 2 as part of the sanctions policy, we do not need any common army. Even in order to give greater defense to the Baltic states on the forum of the Atlantic Alliance, we do not need to create a common army. In fact, new institutions can be created when our solidarity grows. Today there is no evidence of this, what is more, we are dealing in the European Union with an irresponsible authority that caused the immigration crisis. New instruments are not being given to those who do not know what to do with the power they have today.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, it is not through militarization or repressive measures that there will be more security in Europe. With an increase in military spending, they intend to reinforce a repressive and military apparatus to defend the interests of transnational corporations, security and armaments companies and also to continue to impose neoliberal policies that concentrate even more wealth on the already wealthy and continue to deprive the popular classes of their rights and the right to a dignified life and also the poor of their natural resources, common goods and the right to development. Against the increase in military spending and repressive policies, against the European Union of defense, we want more public education and more public health for all and for everyone around the world. We want them to give back to peoples the right to decide, to work and to develop based on their resources, in harmony with the conservation of the environment.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, as you know on 14 November the High Representative, Vice-President Mogherini, presented to foreign and defence ministers the implementation plan on security and defence. This is part of the wider package, together with the Commission’s European Defence Action Plan and concrete proposals for the implementation of a joint declaration on EU/NATO cooperation, signed in Warsaw. The adoption of the related Council conclusions last Monday is a major step forward for the EU, as it opens a new chapter for all the security and defence efforts in the union. A stronger Europe is what we need now more than ever, in view of the unprecedented security challenges we are facing. This is what our citizens and our partners expect from us. I would like to welcome Mr Urmas Paet’s report on the European Defence Union. Our views coincide in most of the areas, and the report addresses many critical issues that we have been working on in the security and defence implementation plan for the EU global strategy. The objective is to define our security and defence strategic priorities and to see how common security and defence policy, being part of wider EU efforts, can contribute to tackling today’s and tomorrow’s multifaceted security challenges, as European citizens demand. From this point of view, I am also grateful to Mr Paet for drawing political attention to priority policy areas and issues that need the Member States’ and the European Parliament’s support. I would like to mention in particular capacity building on security and development, permanent structured cooperation, deployability of the battle groups and the strengthening of the defence industry. Mr Paet’s report is a useful asset to our future work and to thinking ahead on how and in what direction should we move in policy issues and also in terms of structures if and when Member States decide that the time has come for a European Defence Union. The three strategic priorities drawn from global strategy are clear: responding to crisis, building capacities of partners, and protecting the Union and its citizens. It is around these three strategic priorities that the Council has defined a new, comprehensive level of ambition for the EU and identified a number of actions to be undertaken in order to implement this level of a mission. Let me mention some of them: setting military and civilian capacity deployment development priorities; deepening defence cooperation, including setting up a coordinated annual review on defence; exploring the possibility of permanent structured cooperation; adjusting European External Action Service structures to improve our planning and conduct capability for Common Security Defence Policy missions and operations; strengthening the EU rapid response toolbox; looking into financing in the area of security and defence, including revision of internal mechanism. I would like to underline a few key principles on which there was broader agreement. First, the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) remains an important instrument for external action. Second, cooperation with our partners is essential, but the EU needs to be able to act autonomously when necessary. And third, collective defence is NATO’s task so ensure full complementarity here. Particularly appreciated is the report’s reference to improving our structures for planning, conduct and situational awareness. In the short-term we will address the gaps we have in the operational planning and conduct for non-executive military options. We will present a proposal as soon as possible on this. It is important to know that we are not creating big new structures, but addressing shortcomings or streamlining the present components. We welcome the report’s strong statements about the need for a fair functioning and transparent internal market and for the Commission’s involvement in supporting defence research. We share the report’s statement that the current fragmentation of the market represents a weakness for the competitiveness of the European defence industry. So the European Defence Action Plan will set out proposals to strengthen the internal market, support the competitiveness of Europe’s industry and foster cooperation. The Council last week encouraged the Commission to support the Member States in implementing the identified capacity priorities, notably through the Action Plan. In particular, the Action Plan will propose ways to ensure an effective implementation of the two defence directives: procurement and transfers. We also welcome the strong support the Parliament has given to launching and providing a significant budget for preparatory action for defence research to be launched next year with a view to a substantial future defence research program under the next multiannual financial framework.  We think the main message is that today’s complex security challenges can only be tackled together. Therefore, we need a shared vision, a strategic framework and common actions. Cooperation in the field of security and defence is a must.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The point is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday November 23, 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written. - With the arrival of Trump, it is increasingly clear that we will no longer automatically be able to count on the support of the US for our security. We are facing the moment when we need to step up efforts and coordination of our police and military services to combat the terrorist threat effectively and to guard our external borders efficiently. Bilateral cooperation projects must become the stepping stone to programs in which we coordinate defense efforts much more at European level. The Belgian-Dutch renewal of the defense fleet is already setting a good example. The EU-28 spends EUR 195 billion on defense every year. If we better coordinate those expenditures, we can save up to 26 billion euros and therefore use them more wisely. The battle groups must evolve into permanent multinational forces under one European command. They should not only be used for peacekeeping operations, but form a single bloc within NATO that can act if NATO does not want or cannot. Europe is still a peace project and primarily resolves conflict at the negotiating table. In dire times, however, we must send a clear signal that we are ready to act as one block. Don't mess with Europe.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The EU must act urgently to strengthen both its internal security and external defenses in the context of immigration, terrorism and the new US administration. European citizens need a realization of European actions through a substantial review of the Common Security and Defense Policy to allow the EU to act where NATO does not. I believe that the future European space strategy must be taken into account at the next EU summit in December, which will address the strengthening of EU cooperation on external security and defense. The EU must become a real space power, and technology plays a key role as it conditions access to space and competitiveness. We are still very dependent on basic non-European sources when it comes to primordial space technologies. For the moment, we cannot say that Europe is a "space power". For the time being, European access to key space technologies is ensured with the consent of the US authorities. Therefore, the future Common Security and Defense Policy needs to be more effective and visible, all the more so as space capabilities have become an essential part of Member States' security and defense policies and therefore of their sovereignty.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - It is not right that a European citizen does not feel safe within the EU. Russian aggression, the threat of terrorism, joint EU border surveillance and the lack of a European army reinforce this feeling. It is therefore not a devil's idea that, if the EU has a central budget, a common foreign policy - and the line can continue for a long time - then EU soldiers should protect our external borders and be responsible for the security of European citizens. The shocking Brexit vote and the downsizing of the North Atlantic Military Alliance will only reinforce this need of the European defense community. It is time for Europe to take responsibility for its own security. With a common EU army, a European military headquarters, a rapid reaction international corps, a defense council of defense ministers, Europe can be a much more confident superpower. With a common army, we can show aggressive neighbors like Putin’s Russia in recent years that we are serious about protecting EU values ​​and borders. If there is an EU army, we will stone two things: the EU's voice will be much stronger on the international stage, and war between European nations can never break out.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - In addition to new types of security challenges, the political and military necessity of establishing the European Defense Union has been created by the EU's deteriorating security environment over the years, the threat to our southern and eastern neighborhoods. I support rapid EU decision-making to this end, as the main meaning of building European defense autonomy is to take responsibility for the security of EU Member States, especially in the light of Putin's unscrupulous and - not unfounded - threats from Russia's aggression. The role of the EP in shaping the necessary political will is important, because EU solidarity cannot be relied on solely by the governments of the Member States in the field of EU solidarity. The one-way, selfish conception of solidarity and the neglect of one's own defense capabilities have so far prevented the leaders of some countries from considering the defense guarantees of their allies. There are also Member States, such as Hungary, ruled by the Orbán regime, where existing defense capabilities are deployed for anti-democratic domestic policy goals (mass control, law enforcement, border control) that run counter to EU values. However, we also expect the European Defense Union to protect our common European values ​​and to maintain the Union's prestige as an international flag bearer for democracy and human rights. That is why I urge that appropriate political and legal guarantees be included in the system already in the preparatory phase of the Defense Union in order to prevent such 'sloppy' behavior by Member States.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – Madam President, the EU security environment is deteriorating considerably, which coincides paradoxically with flagging defence investments in the Union. That is why I welcome Mr Urmas Paet’s report on the European Defence Union (EDU), whose establishment is indeed a matter of urgency. I strongly agree with the report that the Lisbon Treaty provides already a solid basis for the EDU. One of the remarkable examples of that is Article 42(6) on permanent structured cooperation which has never been used. Therefore, I am very glad that the report calls finally for the creation of a permanent council of defence ministers. In addition, it is important that the report brings to life Article 41(3) on creating the military start-up fund. It does so through establishing a preparatory action for a future EU defence research programme. This can become a first crucial step in overcoming the obstacles among Member States regarding the collective procurement of defence resources which should be at level of 35%, according to the European Defence Agency benchmark. Consequently, I hope that this time Member States will take their obligations seriously and a fully-fledged EDU will become a reality sooner rather than later.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the report by Keith Taylor, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on harnessing the potential of water passenger transport (2015/2350 (INI)) (A8-0306/ 2016).

name: Michael CRAMER
text: deputy rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Keith Taylor is unfortunately not here this week because he is in the hospital and asked me to present the report here for him. It is about the transport of people on inland waterways and also by sea. This report covers both ferry services and cruises, both maritime and inland waterway transport. We have succeeded in putting these issues higher on the EU transport policy agenda, and for this Mr Keith Taylor would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their good support. Of course, sustainability also plays a major role here. There are of course non-fossil renewable energy sources. For example there is a ferry, a zero-emission ferry on the Baltic Sea and many other things. After Paris and Marrakech, we have to include the ships in this objective. This applies particularly to sulfur emissions, and we are happy that the IMO has now decided that sulfur should be reduced to 0.5% worldwide. In the EU we are at 0.1% in the northern areas and that is all going in the right direction. Transport by water should of course also minimize external costs and internalize external costs, but this does not only apply to waterways, but to all modes of transport, because we have unfair competition between the different modes of transport: on the one hand, at the expense of environmentally friendly ones Types of transport, and that is the waterways and the railroad, and in favor of the climate-damaging modes of transport, that is the road and air traffic. The report also pays a lot of attention to safety: through better qualifications and education and through training of staff. All of this should be strengthened and the criteria of the IMO, these are minimum criteria that the EU should at least note, but they can also be reinforced.The quality and accessibility of ferry and cruise services must be optimized; in particular, all people with disabilities must have the opportunity to board these ships.There must be no discrimination against the disabled there.It's all very important.In conclusion, Mr Taylor would once again like to thank the shadow rapporteurs very warmly for their good support and cooperation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I want to support the importance of water transport, also with regard to the specific topic of the Danube-Odra-Elbe transport link.It is one of the segments that remains fallow so far.It is the wealth of both the Czech Republic and Poland and the countries that follow this water transport route.I think that we should also assess these projects from a European point of view and motivate these countries to make this transport connection.In this way, I commented on only one part of water transport and its importance in terms of economics, but it is not only important in terms of economic results.It is also important from the point of view of our safety, because it allows a greater modality of transport connections and, secondly, it allows, for example, to bring water to those parts where they already feel the lack of these water resources.This is a very broad issue, and I thank the rapporteur and his deputy for presenting this report.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, a few weeks ago I participated in the Conference of Peripheral Maritime Regions, which took place in the Azores Islands, and there I had the opportunity to present the importance of connectivity and accessibility for the outermost regions, which are crucial for the competitiveness, the three main axes of expression and implementation of European policy towards the outermost regions. But also to show that the budget allocation of the Connecting Europe Mechanism for the outermost regions has already been exhausted at 86% and, therefore, that it is essential to increase this budget item, precisely to improve the insertion of the regions. outermost in the European internal market and thus to compensate for this competitiveness deficit that affects remote regions, fragmented regions, island regions, in relation to connectivity. And for the maritime transport of the outermost regions, which, in addition to air, is absolutely crucial to sustain their way of life, based on trade, services and, above all, tourism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, 75% of Europe's trade with third countries and 40% of freight trade within Europe take place by sea, while at the same time around 400 million people in Europe use watercraft every year. There are many places in Europe where ferry transportation would be more sustainable, easier and faster increasing the social and economic life in each region. In addition, increasing maritime transport could provide vital services to remote communities and areas, thus helping to revitalize tourism potential. The European Union must therefore strengthen maritime transport so that the inhabitants of the island regions, and in particular the Aegean islands, which are constantly affected by refugee flows, have continued access to the hinterland. We must therefore take important steps.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, the development of transport via maritime and inland waterways has potential economic and environmental benefits in terms of the mobility of passengers and goods. The development of this means of transport can be a factor that induces territorial, social and economic cohesion, in addition to contributing to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In recent years, the disinvestment in equipment and infrastructure and job insecurity in this sector has jeopardized many services. However, the operation of this mode of transport requires the adaptation of natural conditions and infrastructure, which requires investment. Right from the start, public investment, to stimulate, guide and frame private investment. From our point of view, the solution does not involve privatization, deregulation, or more public-private partnerships, but rather strong public intervention and protagonism, as an essential condition for the materialization of the potential benefits of this means of transport and for the resolution existing problems and difficulties.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I focused on passenger water transport last year in the CONT report.Here, the European Court of Auditors has stated that there has been no very positive long-term increase in both freight and passenger water transport due to the fact that many countries invest money only in partial repairs of some ports, but do not seek to widen river navigation.Here we must point out that drought is also a huge problem in domestic shipping.Many rivers struggle with not being navigable enough all year round, and this can lead to huge economic problems for shipowners and the various groups operating in the sector.I would therefore like to call on the Commission to address this issue in its longer-term strategy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the Croatian part of the Adriatic has about seven hundred islands and five hundred islets and reefs.About fifty Croatian islands are inhabited.I myself live on the island of Korcula, the second most populous on the Croatian coast, and I can confirm that poor transport connections with the mainland is one of the main reasons for the economic and demographic extinction of the island.I therefore particularly support the rapporteur in emphasizing the importance of ferry and other ferry lines for islands and their inhabitants.I agree with him that the connection of islands with areas where economic and industrial growth is taking place is crucial for territorial, social and economic cohesion.Better transport connections between the island and the mainland would reduce the dependence of the island's economy on tourism and fisheries and provide a more permanent source of income for citizens, but also for local self-government units, which could then further invest in infrastructure.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission and, in particular, my colleague Commissioner Bulc, I would like to welcome this initiative.  This report is indeed timely. We are convinced it will give further momentum to our maritime year 2017. The issues the report raises are very much the ones we want to work on. We want to ensure safe, secure and sustainable maritime transport that serves the internal market, connects Europe globally and keeps the EU maritime cluster competitive. Waterborne passenger transport is part of this story with the role it plays in people’s daily lives, for their leisure and for the employment it provides to many Europeans. So we welcome the fact that the report looks into passenger transport and leisure activities.  However, in some cases there are differences that should be recognised, for example, when it comes to financial assistance to transport operators linked to public service obligations, which is not generally available to cruise services. Regarding environmental aspects, limits on the sulphur content of shipping emissions were included in EU legislation in 2012 with effect from 1 January 2015. The International Maritime Organisation recently confirmed the global sulphur cap, as of 2020, in line with EU legislation. In 2013 the Commission set up the European Sustainable Shipping Forum, bringing together stakeholders to facilitate the implementation of environmental legislation in the maritime sector. In this framework a Green Shipping Guarantee Programme was developed and launched by the Commission in cooperation with the European Investment Bank this year. This programme is aimed at providing guarantees to accelerate investments in clean maritime technologies and to help the industry to go beyond the current EU environmental legislation. A first framework agreement with national financial institutions was recently signed, to be followed by others later this year. The total financial envelope of EUR 750 million approved for the Green Shipping Guarantee Programme is provided by the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Fund for Strategic Investment. Clean and sustainable shipping will be further promoted with the effective implementation of the directive on the development of alternative fuels infrastructure, ensuring the necessary standardisation and setting up of the basic fuel supply infrastructure between 2025 with EU financial support. The European Maritime Safety Agency will assist with the drafting of technical guidance to port authorities and administrations for liquefied natural gas bunkering. The TEN-T guidelines and their main financing instrument, the Connecting Europe Facility, supports the promotion of green shipping. In this context, over EUR 185 million were allocated in 2014 and 2015 for studies, pilot actions and infrastructure projects to support new technologies and innovation in processes. With regard to transport provided by ferries, integration with other means of transport, including integrated ticketing, is indeed important and, through the ITS Directive, technical and functional specifications are being developed. This will include timetables, as well as information, for passengers with reduced mobility. The Commission notes Parliament’s interest in extending passenger rights to multimodal journeys, in line with the principles enshrined in the current passenger rights regulations, among others the Waterborne Passengers’ Rights Regulation. The Commission is currently looking into possible initiatives in this field. In May 2016 the Commission submitted its report on the operation of the Waterborne Passengers’ Rights Regulation. Stakeholders and national authorities expressed their satisfaction with the regulation, but also agreed that further coordinated action, such as information campaigns to inform citizens about their rights, and cooperation between authorities to ensure the uniform application of the regulation, is needed to improve the regulation’s effectiveness.  The Commission welcomes the interest of Parliament in the question of the international governance of inland waterway transport. This issue is relevant both for passenger and freight transport and, in the context of the Commission’s NAIADES II programme, important steps of streamlining and regulatory convergence have already been taken through the creation, in the framework of the CCNR, of the European Committee for drawing up standards in the field of inland navigation. The Commission would also support the call to have more statistical data on passenger numbers, but it must be underlined that Eurostat can only collect data on the basis of legislation. Harmonised rules for accident statistics exist and a detailed report is published every year. Unfortunately this is not the case for inland waterways. Finally, the Commission fully agrees that ports play an important role in the performance of waterborne passenger transport and has already, since 2013, proposed a comprehensive ports policy. This includes measures to improve the efficiency of ports. We therefore count on your vote in favour of the Ports Regulation, which the Council and Commission expect to go to the plenary without much delay. We also count on your support in promoting good use of the EU’s instruments for finance and investments, notably the Connecting Europe Facility and EFSI.  The Commission believes that ports cannot develop in isolation from their neighbourhoods and thus encourages initiatives that improve the relationship between ports and port cities. Let me also use this opportunity to thank Parliament for its support in relation to issues on securing our external sea borders and the decisions on European coastguard cooperation.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 22 November 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- We are well aware that the Italian maritime transport system needs to be improved in some aspects and in the report we are going to vote it is proposed to boost competitiveness and improve infrastructure.Furthermore, special attention is paid to environmental sustainability, promoting compliance with the COP 21 objectives and encouraging the decarbonisation of transport.I believe that the environmental aspect represents a very important and delicate issue to which a lot of attention must be paid.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also take place. I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. A form of transport that can also benefit tourism can be developed because it allows tourism to flourish along the waterway. In this way, it can also contribute to the economic recovery of a lesser-known region, the creation of new jobs and the creation of small businesses. It is very important to me that the majority of passengers carried on domestic voyages travel on ships that meet common EU safety standards. This requires appropriate training for staff that is accepted across Europe. I view the importance of the report as positive and will support it with my vote.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- Thus, for those of us who use shipping services primarily for holiday purposes, and even more for those who depend on them on a daily basis, the availability and good connection of shipping services with other transport connections is important.It is important to properly involve shipping passenger transport in projects that promote transport multimodality, such as the integrated European ticketing system.trans-European transport networks and the Connecting Europe Facility.I welcome the report, which draws attention to a series of necessary changes in shipping, which would increase its use with many positive consequences, such as less congestion on the roads.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The success of European transport policies will largely depend on how the European Union manages to redirect transport flows in all existing ways, as well as on the quality of services provided. Against the background of a growing demand, but also in the context of a growing concern for reducing emissions, water transport can be the solution of a sustainable and safe transport, which will give a new impetus to economic development in riparian and coastal areas. . For these reasons, Member States and the Commission should pay more attention to passenger water transport, starting with the rehabilitation of the necessary infrastructure and ending with rigorous training of staff in this sector. Better use of this mode would have significant effects on connectivity, especially in remote areas, and would also contribute to the development of the tourism industry, providing improved access to European tourist destinations. It is therefore necessary for the European Executive to step up cooperation with the Member States in order to attract European funds, especially those for SMEs and cohesion policies, in order to draw up a transport strategy appropriate to the needs of each region, but also in relation to with the priorities of the TEN-T network.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Cristian Dan Preda, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation (2016/2139(INI)) (A8—0322/2016).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: protractor. - Madam President, I am very happy that our Parliament is voting tomorrow on the text that I initiated and drafted in the Committee on Development. This will give us the opportunity to present our position ahead of the high-level meeting of the global partnership for effective development cooperation, to be held next week in Nairobi. This meeting is of crucial importance for the theme of development effectiveness since it is the first meeting of this type after the adoption of the Agenda 2030. For us, it is essential that the European Union adopts a strong position in Nairobi by insisting with determination on the need to build on the acquis in terms of development effectiveness and to strengthen existing cases of cooperation. The four principles of development effectiveness, namely ownership of development strategies, results orientation, inclusive partnership, transparency and reciprocal accountability are, in fact, as recognized in the draft outcome document. of Nairobi, the driving forces for the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Now is the time to act to make our development cooperation as effective as possible to achieve these ambitious goals and make the best use of public and private resources for development. Even if it is particularly suited to certain contexts, official development assistance cannot do everything, especially in the current economic context. It should complement countries' efforts to mobilize domestic resources and help catalyze private investment and additional public resources. Nevertheless, we must still insist on respecting the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development - and we are still far from it - as well as on additional efforts in terms of the quality of aid. provided. On issues like untying aid or aligning with country priorities, progress must be accelerated. Since we are talking about the mobilization of resources for development, I must in particular stress the role of the private sector. I believe that it is an important partner in achieving the SDGs and, like other development actors elsewhere, it must commit to aligning itself with the principle of development effectiveness. Beyond the private sector, the Nairobi meeting should also be an opportunity to reaffirm the importance of inclusiveness and partnerships with all actors to achieve the SDGs. We need synergies between the various development actors to achieve this and realize the full potential of these partnerships. The comprehensive partnership for effective development cooperation has an important role to play in this regard. It is essential to strengthen it, including in terms of monitoring, so that it is well positioned in the overall architecture for the implementation of Agenda 2030. The European Union, which has been one of the pioneers development aid effectiveness, must continue to play a leadership role on these issues as well as on the participation of civil society, national parliaments and other stakeholders, South-South cooperation, equality gender and women's empowerment. Responsibility for development results is certainly shared and, with Agenda 2030, we have an additional demand that results from the overall philosophy of leaving no one behind. Finally, there is a whole reflection, which we have developed in this report, which seems to me to be absent from the Nairobi draft final document. I think we have to insist on this point. Development effectiveness cannot be guaranteed without peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law. We therefore advocate for increased support for improving transparency, good governance and the rule of law in developing countries.They are as essential to achieving the SDGs as the other more technical prescriptions of the global agenda for development effectiveness.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! At the outset, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Preda, on his excellent report, in which the topic of increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation was treated taking into account its complexity and multidimensionality. We are discussing this report - as the rapporteur has mentioned - exactly one week before the meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation, which aims to take stock and evaluate the implementation of the Busan principles. It is important to clarify the action program in terms of implementing the SDGs, which should be at the heart of the cooperation framework, as well as the provisions of Addis Ababa for its financing. It is important to emphasize the need for concrete and measurable effects of development policy, because not only the amount of support is important, but also the way in which we provide it and what we allocate it for. Therefore, the involvement and political will of the authorities of the beneficiary countries, as well as the involvement of local actors and civil society in the process, is of particular importance.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, the European Union is the world's largest donor, with almost 55% of the funds allocated worldwide. However, we face a number of difficulties: whether we are talking about the medium- and long-term impact of development assistance funds, whether we are talking about the inadequacy of joint projects between Member States, or whether we are sometimes talking about financing the same projects. by several Member States or from several budget lines. All these problems, however, can be solved with a series of concrete solutions. In order to increase the efficiency of development assistance funds, we need to regulate the allocation of assistance at European level. We need to develop comprehensive monitoring and support programs for beneficiaries both during and after the projects. We need to increase transparency in the allocation and spending of funds, but at the same time we need to create a public system for reporting on European funding and projects. Because, ultimately, what needs to be done is to find a way to coordinate all the projects developed by the European Union and the Member States. The problem of efficiency can be solved if we want this and we fight for it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the UN 2030 Agenda is an ambitious set of seventeen objectives for sustainable development and poverty eradication. More effective aid and development cooperation remain key factors in combating unemployment and empowering local communities. The policy pursued by the European Union in recent years is far from helping its Member States to achieve these goals. Merkel austerity and the imposition of memoranda in Greece have increased unemployment, created armies of the unemployed, increased rates of poverty and social exclusion. During the years of the memorandum crisis, the percentage of households living in Greece in conditions of absolute poverty doubled in 2015 and reached over 22%. If the European Union really wants to achieve the 2030 targets, it must abandon its austerity policy, a policy that affects development, and make a real contribution to debt relief in both the periphery and the developing countries. Countries.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, more than half of the world's development aid is currently provided by the EU and its Member States. However, the success of development policies depends on the effectiveness of international development cooperation as well as cooperation on sustainable development. We need to see that international mechanisms, while a serious commitment and in many cases the only help in a given situation, can only produce very limited results. The slow decline of global inequalities cannot compensate for environmental changes, the problem of water scarcity, and the migration that partly results from them, some of the consequences of explosive population growth. The developed world can only demonstrate its commitment to achieving the goals with a stronger and more ambitious development policy and an adjustment to international trade mechanisms.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - The influx of migrants from Africa to Italy, which will not weaken even in bad weather, is probably the most critical testimony of us as providers of development aid, but also of the governments of developing countries that are its official recipients.That is why I am very pleased that we in this House regularly seek to monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of the funds spent on an ongoing basis, draw attention to shortcomings in the application of the agreed rules and propose improvements.At the same time, however, I am sorry that neither Slovakia, whose citizens I represent here, nor the other 22 EU Member States have been able to contribute as much as they have committed to development aid.As if we do not understand that any reduction in these funds will pay off in the form of rising spending on border protection and saving lives.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, the debate on the effectiveness of development aid is recurrent in this Parliament, a discussion that is not without some hypocrisy. It is that, while some here unravel a list of extensive concerns, they forget that it is the policies that are decided here that, to a large extent, hampered the development possibilities of the least developed countries, the deregulation and liberalization of trade international movement to the free circulation of capital, of which tax havens are a privileged instrument, including agricultural and fisheries policies, among other examples. Covered by these concerns, what some want, in fact, is to impose on developing countries models of political, economic and social organization, the sacrosanct market economy, erected as a panacea for all ills, humanity, the role of the private sector, the opening of markets to world competition, forgetting that, as Lacordaire recalled, between the weak and the strong, between the rich and the poor, it is freedom that oppresses and it is the law that liberates. The solution is to change policies, not to insist on the same paths that brought us here.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! We have been discussing the need to make development aid more effective for more than 10 years, and while the progress that has been made since then should be appreciated, there are still many aspects to be worked on. From my point of view, two of them are particularly important: first, I am convinced that it is very important to increase cooperation between donors and reduce aid fragmentation. According to a study by the European Commission, eliminating the fragmentation of aid would save as much as two to three billion euros a year, which could be successfully used for poverty eradication. The second important issue is the intensive efforts to increase stability, peace and the rule of law in partner countries. As shown by many studies, the effectiveness of development aid is much higher in countries with a higher democratic index, and therefore also for this reason such activities are extremely necessary.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I welcome the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. It provides an important input to the second High-Level Meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC). The development effectiveness agenda and GPEDC marked a shift from aid to development effectiveness, moving the focus from official development assistance flows to broader development partnerships and actors.  Five years after the forum held in Busan, Korea, it is a good moment to assess the implementation of commitments taken and to discuss how effective development cooperation can best contribute to implementing the 2030 Agenda on sustainable development and the Addis Ababa Action Plan on financing for development.  The EU should continue to lead and move these agendas forward. The new European consensus for development, which will guide the EU and Member States’ development policy in the years ahead will help develop effectiveness at its heart. We need to consider not just what we do, but how we do it.  Important steps have been taken to advance a more strategic and coordinated EU approach, for example by advancing a joint programming of EU and Member States development assistance; maximising our collective impact and minimising overlaps; increasing transparency of aid and mutual accountability; measuring results on the basis of our new results framework; promoting ownership of the development priorities by partner countries, and addressing conflict and fragility.  Nevertheless, in order to implement the 2030 Agenda successfully, more needs to be done at both EU and global level. The Commission believes that the Global Partnership should strengthen the political momentum behind effective development cooperation and support implementation of these principles and commitments at country level. It should promote multi-stakeholder platforms at country level and the use of available data to enhance dialogue. If strategically developed and used, the Global Partnership can indeed provide added value to other international fora in the implementation, thus contributing to the follow-up process of the 2030 Agenda.  The report rightly recognises that the specific value added of the Global Partnership is in its inclusive and multi-stakeholder character, and stresses the need for all actors to be involved in moving the effectiveness agenda forward. In order to become a true partnership of all relevant actors, the involvement of parliaments, civil society organisations, local authorities and private sector is essential. Averting situations of fragility also entails closer cooperation, notably with humanitarian actors, to build the resilience of vulnerable populations.  The private sector and providers of south-south cooperation can make a huge contribution to achieving the sustainable development goals. We need to improve our ways of working in partnership, such as through the recently proposed External Investment Plan and dialogues with southern providers. We also need to see action and commitments from these actors. We would like the outcome document of the Nairobi High-Level Meeting to include their ideas on how they will implement the principles in practice. The Global Partnership brings a special perspective by focusing on relations between development actors, but also through monitoring the progress of the implementation of principles and commitments. The recently published 2016 progress report entitled ‘Making Development Cooperation More Effective’ is a valuable source of evidence-based information to stimulate policy dialogue at country, regional and international level.  To conclude, I would like to stress the Commission’s commitment to development policy principles – results, transparency, country ownership and inclusive partnerships. We call on all development partners to ensure that the Nairobi High Level Meeting further enhances the contribution of the Global Partnership to the 2030 Agenda. The Commission is committed to keeping the European Parliament and its relevant committees informed on the advancement of Global Partnership.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 22 November 2016.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
