text: - The whole of Europe is facing tachometer fraud.Is it possible to do something about it?I definitely think so.Belgium and the Netherlands have already introduced a car pass system that allows fraud to be combated effectively.Both countries can thus inspire other states.Unfortunately, even measures at national level cannot prevent the tachometers from overturning for cars imported from another state.That is why I have been fighting for individual car pass systems for the entire EU for the third year in a row.The negative consequences of tachometer fraud tend to be far-reaching and the biggest victims are poor consumers.They buy a car at a price that does not correspond to its real value.I therefore ask, Commissioner, how long will we stand idly by for these practices?

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, energy poverty cannot wait.That is why I have decided to intervene in this debate at this time of night to demand measures, measures for those millions of people in Europe who cannot pay their electricity bill or who have to choose between food and electricity.Recently, in Spain, we have experienced a dramatic situation that sensitized many citizens;But it is not necessary that these things have to happen so that we are all sensitized, so that the European Commission takes action, so that these measures are urgent.You have to act.We cannot look the other way.Only the abandonment of responsibility, only not having sensitivity, only situations that are being and demanding a response have to be addressed immediately.If we do not do so, we will be contributing to this type of situation remaining and the situations becoming more terrible and moving us more and more.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, at the end of October in Orašje in Bosnia and Herzegovina, 10 members of the Croatian Defense Council, a military formation that was the first to defend Bosnia and Herzegovina from Serbian aggression, were arrested. Among those arrested are retired officers of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia, a NATO member state. All these people have lived in Bosnia and Herzegovina since the end of the war and are available to the judiciary. Interestingly, they have not been prosecuted for war crimes all these years. Even more interestingly, whenever the issue of the internal reorganization of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the revision of Dayton and the equality of Croats is raised, the political persecution of Croatian defenders begins, either on the orders of Sarajevo or Banja Luka. If Brussels really sees Bosnia and Herzegovina's European perspective, I think the time has finally come to send a clear message to Sarajevo that the judiciary must not be used for political purposes and that further harassment of Croatian citizens, members of the European Union, will not be tolerated.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, on Wednesday this Parliament will vote on a resolution that I co-authored with other MEPs. This resolution asks Parliament to refer the Canadian trade deal, CETA, to the European Court of Justice to decide if the proposed investor protection courts are compatible with the EU Treaties.  These investor protection courts appoint their own judges and they are not answerable to national or European courts. President Juncker, in one of his first speeches to this House, said: ‘My Commission will not accept that the jurisdiction of courts in EU Member States be limited by special regimes for investor-to-state disputes’. Yet that is exactly what is happening.  I am horrified that Ireland has provisionally signed this deal without rigorous debate and vote in our Dáil. We are the only country in the EU not to have these special investor courts in our legislation and yet we will leave ourselves open to multi-million-euro claims in these courts if we agree the deal. Our Seanad voted to reject the deal and the very least our Dáil can do is to debate and vote on CETA. In this context I hope this Parliament will vote on Wednesday to support the resolution if for nothing else but to have legal certainty.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). Madam President, last week at a conference in Frankfurt, the German Finance Minister launched a slanderous attack on Greece. He falsely claimed that the Greeks are living beyond their means, while the Greek current account balance was already almost balanced by 2015 and has become a surplus of more than one billion euros for 2016. This surplus has been achieved with huge sacrifices of the Greek people. in the last seven years, which Mr Schäuble has no right to ignore. Equally false is his claim that pensions in Greece are still high, when the average new pension is now at the level of about 660 euros, ie only marginally above the minimum decent living standard based on current price levels. With all this, Mr Schäuble demagogues and undermines the European idea.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Madam President, this week we will vote on the Fotyga report which accuses Russia of engaging in propaganda against the West. But where is the condemnation of anti-Russian propaganda? One recent example: on 11 November 2016 my country, Latvia, celebrated Bear Slayer’s Day, which commemorates the victory of Latvian independence fighters in 1919 over the troops of German-backed warlord Pavel Bermont-Avalov. On 14 November the Financial Times Europe published an article saying that Bear Slayer’s Day honoured Latvian freedom fighters who secured independence against Russian forces. This year, US troops were in Riga for the commemoration — part of NATO’s attempt to reassure the Baltic states in the face of a ‘renewed threat from the big bear to the east’ (end of quote). But Bermont-Avalov did not represent any Russian Government, neither that of Imperial Russia nor that of Soviet Russia. His idea was to create a pro-German Baltic duchy. The blatant Russophobic propaganda based on false historical facts must be punished, a serious manifestation of racism and xenophobia. We must not allow historic misrepresentation to stand in the way of reconciliation.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President! The President-elect of the United States is not going to sign the TTIP, and I think this is a godsend. TTIP does not stand for free trade per se. Most TTIP proponents are in favor of trade sanctions, for example against Russia. They are not free traders. The program of our party, the AfD, says literally: “International trade is the basis of our prosperity and peaceful coexistence. We consider economic sanctions to be fundamentally wrong. ”We want to dismantle trade barriers in Europe and worldwide. That is a clear free trade position. And that's good. Because wherever goods do not cross borders, armies will. Those who demand sanctions from Russia are not promoting peace. I am therefore pleased that the Eastern Committee of German Business has spoken out in favor of stopping the EU's punitive measures against Russia. Thanks for that. It is an urgent step towards normalizing our relations with Russia.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, despite his applause from the SYRIZA-ANEL government, US President Obama did not visit Greece either out of admiration for its history or out of sympathy for its people. His intervention on the Greek debt requires tougher anti-popular measures. The goal was the geopolitical interests of US and NATO intervention, together with the European Union, in the Middle East, the Mediterranean, the Aegean to control the Russian presence. They, together with the governments of Greece, Turkey and Cyprus, are promoting the division of Cyprus as a stable base for energy investors in the region. No word was said on the Turkish government's questioning of the border. It agreed with the Greek government on its further involvement and new military facilities, putting the Greek people and the neighboring peoples in immediate danger. Trump, Obama and Clinton: they are not separated by chaos; they have the same disgusting imperialist strategy. The people must be worried and not choose between Scylla and Charybdis. They must chart their own independent way of overthrowing capitalism, which holds only poverty, unemployment, wars and refuge for the peoples.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to welcome the agreement in principle on visa-free travel for Ukraine, which I hope will soon be followed by a positive conclusion to the process. Ukraine has chosen the path of European integration for two years, which is a cause for concern for the education reform on the agenda, which amends the article on the language of education in the Education Act at the expense of national minorities. According to the bill, ethnic students would have the right to education in their mother tongue only in addition to the Ukrainian language, only at primary and secondary level, and only in places where the given national minority lives in one block. Human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the rights of national minorities, are important elements of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. Thus, the bill contradicts international obligations, but also violates the constitutional rights of national minorities in Ukraine. I hope that this non-European process, which represents a major step backwards in the practice of minority rights, can still be stopped and that Ukraine will strive to become a rule of law that respects its minorities.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, respect for human rights is regulated both at European level and at the level of each Member State. However, there are serious violations of citizens' rights in many Member States. And, unfortunately, this seriously and sometimes irreparably affects people's lives and dignity. The case of the citizen Mariana Rarinca from my country is well-known and, therefore, I consider this example eloquent for my statement. Ms Rarinca, from the applicant in relation to the president of the SCM in Romania, became accused. She was arrested 191 days before being tried. This lady's ordeal lasted for years and, finally, after she was acquitted, she was convicted again. The Rarinca case is a typical case in which the simple citizen fights with the institutions for justice and fails to win. It is serious, in this case, that both the SCM institution and the presidential institution did not comply with the legal provision regarding the fifteen-day period granted to a citizen to file an appeal. I believe that, from here, at European level, we must monitor the institutions of a rule of law so that they act separately, in a non-discriminatory manner, in compliance with human rights. And I also believe that the lack, in the legislation of some states, of the responsibility of the magistrates leads to abuses and sufferings, but also to the spending of huge sums from the budget for the compensations of the citizens who, in the end, find justice in European institutions.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - The current authorities of the European Union bear joint responsibility for the escalation of the immigration crisis and the accompanying tragedies. If the Union had the principles of political responsibility, the common good, and finally democracy, this European Commission would have been dismissed by this Parliament long ago. Article 79 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union clearly recognizes that combating illegal immigration is a task for the Union, a duty towards our countries. Meanwhile, the Commission not only continues its destructive policy, but also creates new conflicts by putting pressure on our countries to activate the mechanism of forced sending immigrants around Europe. Meanwhile, the countries of Central Europe, including Poland - my country - are not guided by any selfishness in this matter, but by responsibility towards future generations. Anyone who does not understand this is not only against our freedom, but also against the future of Europe.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the enlargement process in the Balkans is complex and challenging. If we do not handle it right it might be an extremely long process. Meanwhile, Russian influence in the region is increasing; pro-Russian candidates are winning in Bulgaria and Moldova. Part of Bosnia – Republika Srpska – is helping to spread Russian influence through energy and several other countries are exposed to organised information campaigns from the Kremlin.  If we do not find a way to stop this, Russia will be a hurdle to the enlargement process and eventually will stop it. We cannot afford this. The EU is having an existential crisis and we need the Balkan countries to show that the EU is still worth joining and that there is a reason for its existence. We need to see the flame of the will of these countries to join the EU. We need these countries as much as they need us. The integration of the Balkans into the EU must be a strategic and urgent asset for us. We cannot allow those who want to destroy the EU to succeed. The enlargement process has to be faster and the Commission must take it steadily forward.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Madam President, we are witnessing yet another black page in the history of this Parliament.In view of the chorus of protests over CETA, reservations raised by parties, associations of all kinds, this Parliament made it impossible to hold a debate that would have had the merit of clarifying its real objectives and confronting each deputy with a free and democratic debate..In this way, we will have a vote on a draft resolution without the right to debate, which says a lot about the quality of democracy that we breathe in this Chamber.CETA was secretly discussed over seven years and was presented in the form of a 1,600-page document, with no possibility of amendment.CETA represents an instrument aimed at opening public markets to multinationals and leveling down all social and environmental standards.This is what Parliament refuses to discuss.Democracy loses, the peoples of Europe lose.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Madam President, very few hours ago we learned that the Supreme Court of Spain has confirmed the sentence that condemned Judge Santiago Vidal for having drawn up an outline of a possible Constitution for Catalonia. He did it in his spare time, without commission from anyone and without prejudice to his exemplary dedication to the judiciary. The judge had been sentenced to three years of suspension of employment and salary. The confirmation of the conviction is so absolutely incredible and ridiculous, so denial of democratic freedom of expression, that it provokes the strongest rejection. Of course, mine, that I am no longer surprised by any decision of the highest Spanish magistrates, because the antecedents of decisions of the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court will one day appear in European manuals as ideological jurisprudence lacking sense of the reality. I am not surprised, but it hurts, and I want the European Parliament to record this new abuse of the Spanish Supreme Court, for now, the last.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, the recent decision of the High Court demonstrates the British establishment’s desire to delay, impede and eventually prevent our exit from the EU. If the Supreme Court upholds the High Court decision it will precipitate a constitutional crisis. This has been possible because our political establishment persists in saying that we can only leave the EU by means of Article 50. We are being led up the garden path so that we can all bark up the wrong tree. We can restore the supremacy of our own law by repealing the European Communities Act 1972. We will then have left the EU. Parliament will have to vote on that anyway, either at the beginning or at the end of the process of disentangling Britain from the European Union. Parliament should accept the vote of the referendum and repeal the act as a first step, not as a last step. Brexit means exit.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - This Friday we will commemorate World Day against Violence against Women.It is an opportunity to condemn all forms of violence and, at the same time, to draw attention to women, who are all too often its victims.I want to live in a world where every woman can feel safe, in a human community that will do its utmost to prevent violence and help its victims, a world where every arbitrary act of violence against a woman is severely punished, regardless of the perpetrator's motives.Violence against a woman is always reprehensible and it does not make sense to examine whether it is directed against a woman as a woman, a woman as a wife or partner, a woman as a colleague or a woman as a casual passer-by on the street.In this spirit, I also welcome the planned debate on the motion for a resolution on the prevention of violence against women, and I will be very happy to take part in it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, my intention today is to report here a case that we have recently suffered in Spain - in Catalonia, in Reus - especially derived from energy poverty, a problem that we have dealt with on some occasions here. Rosa, an eighty-one-year-old woman - that's how her name was: Rosa - died as a result of a fire in her house because Gas Natural, a large Spanish electricity company, cut off her power after two months of non-payment. A candle that she used to light her house eventually caused a fire and her death. This is happening today in European houses: we have five million people who suffer from energy poverty in Spain and fifty in Europe. And it is time for the European Commission to take action on the matter, face clear measures to ensure that companies do not cut the supply or make citizens choose between eating or paying for electricity, make a clear control on rates and impose clear rules to companies in order to send the message that the European Union is there to protect citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, a few hours ago we heard Mr Draghi apologize. He avoided answering the key questions we asked him. He refrained from answering why he has excluded Greece from quantitative easing. He did not say a single apology to the Greek people, whom he went bankrupt as a member of the troika and sent to unemployment. In fact, Mr. Draghi, as the new Pontius Pilate, blamed the Commission. He also said that allegedly there is no decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union to expel the European Central Bank from the troika. To re-read the judgment C 62/2014 of the Court. Read paragraph 30 of last year's report by the European Parliament, which approved my proposal. Mr. Draghi did not say a word about the fact that, by order of the European Central Bank, the Greek banks are selling the loans of the Greeks to the crows who grab their houses. Mr. Draghi also threw the ball on the podium on the issue of the Greek debt, a debt which is odious debt and for which the Greek people must now proceed to write it off. Let Mr. Draghi know, then, that the Greek people will soon throw the troika out of our homeland.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, 2016 is on the way to being another black year for occupational accidents in Spain: accidents with sick leave increase 7.6% and fatal accidents increase deaths by 1.5%: 461 fatalities from exploitation and of greed, of the precariousness of the working class. Data that also fall short, since the fear of many of losing their jobs and the manipulation of mutuals hide many of the illnesses and accidents of which workers are victims. The European Union is responsible, together with the Government of Spain, for the attack on collective bargaining and for the cutback policies that have triggered unemployment, temporary employment and the deterioration of working conditions, as well as the cutback of health and safety resources labor. We demand that the role of inspections and the recognition of occupational diseases be reinforced, with the participation of trade unions and European organizations such as OSHA or the platform against undeclared work, and that in the future pillar of European social rights work dignified, safe, decent, be at the center of the European standard.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Nino Di Matteo in Italy is the prosecutor who investigates the mafia massacres of the 1990s and the relations between the mafia itself and Italian politics. His constant commitment against "Cosa Nostra" has produced an invitation from the Italian state to leave Palermo and Sicily. Those who, like me, grew up in Sicily during the years of the mafia massacres, cannot fail to reconnect the institutional behavior of those terrible years with some events that concern Nino Di Matteo today. The Italian state is, for the umpteenth time, demonstrating that it has no greater fear than to try itself, while the silence of the media amplifies the still current mix between the mafia and politics. For this reason, on behalf of the Italians, I will invite all the deputies of this Parliament to see the documentary produced by Al Jazeera on the most endangered magistrate in Europe. Nino Di Matteo has been trying for twenty years to say that the problem is not the mafia itself, but that it feeds on collusion and political cover. Perhaps it would be time for someone at a European level to become more interested in the mafia phenomenon.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to talk again about the problem of the interconnection of water transport within the European region of Central Europe, and that is the connection of the Danube-Odra-Elbe canal.This is mentioned, among other things, in one of the reports that we will be voting on tomorrow, and I not only support this waterway in the long term, but I would also like to call on the EU institutions to find sufficient support for this project, because it is not in the interests ofonly the Czech Republic, Poland, or Germany, if it were a connection to the Elbe, but also Slovakia and undoubtedly Austria and Hungary.In my opinion, it is also a very strategic investment in our security.It will bring alpine water, connect regions in terms of water transport.It has its undoubted costs, and we must admit it, even in the field of the environment.Nevertheless, I would like to support this project because I see it as a strategic investment in our common future.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Madam President, since 2011, the European Commission and Parliament have joined forces to strengthen transparency through a register which identifies interest representatives who can access the institutions - a laudable effort which should be reinforced by the revision of September 28. Unfortunately, an entire category of influence groups escape these obligations. Indeed, churches and religious communities are purely and simply exempt from registration. These organizations already have, by virtue of Article 17 of the Treaty, privileged access to the European institutions. The minimum would be that they are subject to the same transparency obligations. As co-chair of the European Parliament platform for secularism, I was able to observe, during our meetings, the presence of certain extremist groups, like Civitas, or sectarians, like the Church of Scientology, and the loopholes established by this review can only strengthen their ability to influence our decisions. We know their strike force in this area, and there is no need to make it easier for them. So, in the absence of being able, for the moment, to protect our institutions from the influence of religious groups, let us expose their practices. Too many rights, too many freedoms are at stake to maintain obscurity. It is up to us to shed light and ensure that transparency is the rule.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, recently two EU-funded independent reports into media ownership in Ireland documented the chilling effect Denis O’Brien, one of the largest shareholders of Ireland’s print and broadcast media, is having on media freedom and plurality in Ireland. Now, in spite of his domination of the media industry and his history as a serial litigator of journalists, it is revealed that his sphere of influence stretches to the broadcast media watchdog, the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland (BAI).  In February 2015 a Mr Nigel Heneghan was appointed to the BAI watchdog without public consultation or competition despite his PR company being a client of the same Denis O’Brien by representing his print media company and the business interests of Siteserve. Concerns of conflicts of interest were brushed aside and to this day Mr Heneghan sees no problem with adjudicating on complaints to the watchdog about his client Mr O’Brien’s broadcast companies.  Media freedom in Ireland is under serious threat and the next European Centre for Press and Media Freedom report will likely show no change. It seems that our politicians are too scared to act when it comes to dealing with the media.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, there are many voices in the European public that the fight against corruption in Romania is setting an example for many other states. I myself believe that a great change has taken place in Romania and that the cleansing of public life can be a huge positive in this process. But we cannot pretend not to see the excesses of the system as well. Currently, the Corruption Prosecutor's Office is currently investigating a Catholic Hungarian school operating in a building returned to the Catholic Church under Romanian restitution laws, because it is suspected that irregularities may have occurred in connection with the permitting process. If this has happened, it needs to be rectified, but it is unacceptable that officials are accused of corruption who have only put the law into practice and question the good faith of the school principal, as well as creating insecurity in parents and children. Questioning the legitimacy of schools operating in reclaimed ecclesiastical properties is becoming more common in Romania, fearing that the intention to reverse the entire restitution process will guide those in charge.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Madam President, a few weeks ago it turned out that the family of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán was dealing with an internationally circulated criminal, Saudi billionaire Ghaith Pharaon. Pharaoh has been surrounded by the FBI and Interpol for many years due to, among other things, support for terrorism and the illegal arms trade, but he is not in danger of arrest in Hungary. All the more so as he has just recently bought a high-value property in the immediate vicinity of the Hungarian Prime Minister. All the more so as he is not threatened with arrest because the Hungarian authorities granted him a European visa and a residence permit despite being in international circulation, and they did so without even taking a fingerprint - which would otherwise be required by law -, so that it does not become clear later who was admitted to the country and, because of the European visa, to the whole of the European Union. This is a European scandal, because Pharaoh, this circulated international criminal, can move freely not only in Hungary, but throughout the European Union because of his visa. As the Hungarian authorities have not arrested this criminal, it will be up to the European authorities, Europol, to catch the circulated criminal.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, as the December anniversary of the 1989 Timisoara uprising approaches, former high-ranking leaders of the former and new Romanian secret services are trying to discredit the Romanian anti-communist and anti-securitization Romanian revolution, a Soviet and Hungarian break-up of Transylvania.setting it as a subversion and coup.I would like to draw the attention of the Union and Parliament to the fact that the greatest threat to Romania's democratic transformation is still being the former Securitate, the old-new secret service, which, as a continuation of Ceausescu's National Communist policy, is using the chauvinist anti-Hungarian tool.counter-revolutionary activity.Let's defend the Romanian revolution and the Romanian-Hungarian historical solidarity!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, the European Union's objectives are to stimulate research at European level. But, unfortunately, through the way it implements its programs, it generates new pay discriminations between researchers from Eastern and Western Europe. Despite the fact that the funds are won through competitions at European level, in the main Horizon 2020 research and innovation program there are huge differences between the salary scales applied. I ask, therefore, the European Commission: how is it possible that a type A expert in a European project can earn about 70 euros (300 lei), while the income of the Romanian researcher in the same project is ten times higher small, being reduced to only about seven euros? Thus, I stand in solidarity with the initiative of Babeș Bolyai University in Cluj-Napoca and the Polytechnic University of Bucharest and I firmly ask the European Commission to restore a unitary salary for all European researchers. At equal work, equal pay. As a member of the European Parliament and as a Romanian academic, I cannot accept such discrimination and I will fight to restore justice.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, last month a former Taoiseach (Prime Minister) of Ireland and former EU Ambassador to Washington, John Bruton, appeared before a committee in the British House of Lords to discuss the impact of Brexit, or Britain leaving the EU, on its closest neighbour, Ireland. He said that Brexit might deal Ireland’s economy an even heavier blow then Britain’s, even though we had no say in the referendum. Already we have seen the impact of the changes on sterling. This has had an immediate effect on small businesses, particularly those that export. Their exports are less competitive, they are more expensive on the shelves and when dealing with UK relationships. Imports from Britain are cheaper, thus putting further pressure on small businesses in Ireland. Britain takes two-fifths, or 40%, of exports from Ireland. Beef and dairy are already feeling a strong impact, as is the mushroom sector, which exports 80% of its production to Britain. Undoubtedly, the impact of Brexit on Ireland – as has been said by others and not just in our country – is going to be severe, and it needs to be ensured that this is reflected in the negotiations as we move forward.
